posts.com:
We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

>>2506731
>"Is this any good for America"
Ooooh buddy. you have no idea.
The plant life in northern California is pretty much gonna be 99% different in southern California, is gonna be 90% different than coastal California.
Mostly the only plants that grow all across the entire continent of America are going to be incredibly invasive rhuderal plants that thrive in disturbed soil, as humans sure like to disturb our soil. So like dandelions, Docks, ECT.
Anyways my advice to learn foraging is to not even try to do foraging for at least a few months. Rather buy several plant books about the specific biome you're in in Texas, (desert, forest, plains) and then just try to identify any plants you can cross-referencing between the different books and the internet, with no regard for if the plant is useful. Just try to memorize the subtle differences between any plants you see often.
Eventually you will just come to know what certain plants are definitively, and some of those plants will be the edible ones, then you can safely forage those.
Also sorry if I seemed condescending Im this post. Genuinely wish you luck and believe in you. Plant identification and foraging is probably my biggest hobby.

>>2507683
Ethnobotany books are pretty interesting, sometimes even good. It would be way easier just to tell the area you're looking for information on.
For example--I'm currently in Florida on contract and the number of imported trees and shrubs dwarfs the natives...for example there are 12 (arguably but to keep the math easy) types of native palms (which aeent actually trees) but now there are over 300 species of palms....and the bulk of the sub tropical costal forests used to be predominantly long leaf pine but I'm most areas you'll see oak and Palm with very few pine...so foraging the native stuff is either un swamps or someone's yard. There aren't really any good foraging books for Florida but some are OK, like Florida's wild edibles...also foraging is mostly illegal where all the good stuff grows.
I'm getting ready to go back to the PNW and the story is very different--Plants of the Pacific northwest coast is the gold standard of foraging guides...like the practical guide to northern Idaho wild plants...it's all regional. It's also good to find someone that teaches plant identification either in person or online. I'm starting up a kids program and I'll likely teach the kids and the parents. Ironically it will be on shrub and tree identification...lots if edibles. There are usually local/reigonal mycelium/mushroom clubs that give free classes and will help you identify something either from pictures or samples. You'd be amazed how many mushrooms you can find o
just off of roads if you know the conditions they grow in (usually the trees they grow under). Also, look into tincture making for your reign. Most guidebooks won't tell you how to make an opiate substitute out of Monotropa uniflora but, if you can find it, the tincture people have books.

the debate over what killed Chris McCandless, and the related question of whether he is worthy of admiration, has been smoldering and occasionally flaring for more than two decades now. Shortly after the first edition of Into the Wild was published in January 1996, University of Alaska chemists Edward Treadwell and Thomas Clausen shot down my theory that the cause of McCandless’s death was a toxic alkaloid contained in the seeds of the Eskimo potato plant, Hedysarum alpinum, also known as wild potato. When Treadwell and Clausen completed chemical analyses of the Eskimo potato seeds I’d sent them, they found no trace of any poisonous compounds. “I tore that plant apart,” Dr. Clausen explained to Men’s Journal in 2007. “There were no toxins. No alkaloids. I’d eat it myself.”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Several sets of woolen underwear. Wool socks. Waterproof shoes. Winter sleeping bag. Ideally a sleeping bag liner. Good quality tent. Thick matress or foam layer in tent. Hot water bottle or several chemical heating packs. More gas than you need. If you have the space, a heater. Tbh the stuff you would need to carry to not have a shit trip means it's not really worth it unless you can carry it by sled or pulk. Test all your gear in advance and spend one night in your backyard

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2509392
Wool, lots of fucking wool.
Wool socks, really fucking thick ones.
Wool underwear, top and bottom, really thick ones.
Something that keeps the wind out.
Good boots that are at least 8" high, size up one size.
Mittens for anything that doesn't require fine motor skills, don't use thin gloves.
It was -20 here yesterday, though I'm quite a bit further north than anything in Sweden.
No tight fitting clothes for outer layer, goes for hands and feet too.
Cold is no problem if you are prepared.
You also need more food than normal, and extra dry clothes, change often, socks especially.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2494226
The Strongarm is a great soldier knife, but I maybe wouldn't go with one as an outdoor knife for camping, etc. because the use case is slightly different. The strongarm uses 420HC steel, which is very tough and low maintenance, but it is soft, that's where the toughness comes from, but as a result, it does not hold an edge for a very long time. That's why most of these types of knives come with serrations, so you can still rip through material even if the straight blade is dull.
For camping etc., toughness isn't quite as important as it is for a soldier, so I would go with a knife with harder steel, which will hold an edge longer and be better at working with wood etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2494184
Get a Lionsteel B series. They are the same knife with slight variations in handle shape and blade length, pick the one whose shape you like the most. They make amazing knives for the money, not sure if there's any overhead if you're in the USA but in Europe these go for 120-130 bucks. The steel they use is Sleipnir which is a substantially improved D2, it's tool steel and not stainless so you will have to do a little maintenance with oil to avoid rust but it's tough as shit. The knives are a beefy full tang with a sharpened pommel for lighting firesteels. They can handle batoning and everything else. The grip on mine is phenomenal because of the way it's machined, and they use either wood or materials like micarta or g10. I've got one in micarta and another in g10 they're both amazing. I think the wood they use is "stabilized" which I guess means some kind of polymerising treatment. They're the best knives I've ever handled. Super comfortable, balance, perfect fit & finish, great leather shealths or kydex on the beefier knives.
You can probably get "better" but it's on a whole different price point and IMO you don't need more than that. Scandi knives are memes. You get an "artisanal" carbon steel knife with a stick tang and a sloppy grind because it's "handmade". Very beautiful knives but if you want a good tool I suggest Lionsteel.

A beginner won't be able to pick up a scalpel and use it well. That doesn't mean the scalpel is a bad tool.
A beginner should figure out what works and what doesn't, and should make mistakes to learn what not to do. You can't just jump right to "the best knife" and be happy with it. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2494184
Just get whatever with the following features:
>straight edge, no serrations unless you see yourself cutting thick ropes a lot of time.
>normal edge shape, like clip point, drop point or straight back
>if it's going to be your only cutting tool keep it's edge between 3.5 and 6 inches if you already have a small folder for eating and small tasks feel free to go bigger
>flat grinds like on a mora companion are easier to sharpen if you are a noob, but ultimately it won't really matter
>make sure it has a proper handle, no meme storage compartments or skeletonized handles wrapped with paracord.
>don't sperg about the fancy meme steels, get whatever in a normal carbon steel and learn how to properly care about and sharpen it, then get a fancy steel. In general, cheapo stainless tends to be worse than cheap carbons and are also harder to sharpen.
>big plus if it is full tang, but rat tail will do the job fine enough as long as you don't do stupid shit with your knife. Avoid partial tangs

Picrel is made by the same people who make Fallkniven knives: Hattori knives from Japan. It's called the Hattori S-51. It was commissioned by a military supplier to the ASEAN navy's (Asian version of NATO). They found a box of unassembled blades from the contract a number of years later, completed them, and sold them to the public. I managed to get one. The steel is quite soft due to it needing to be extremely stainless and tough = soft. But it's probably my favourite knife of all mine.

Check out this website, and you'll notice they are very similar to Fallkniven. That's because they are.

>>2494184
It really depends on what you want your knife to do.

I will always have a folding saw and hatchet with me when doing a proper camp, so I don't have to have a knife that can be used to baton and shit.

For a starting knife, Mora knives are ALWAYS a good choice. They're well-made, easy-to-use, and cheap. There are lots of different options, but I like their Kansbol, Classic 2, 2000, Garberg.

Another great choice is to buy a Casström no.10 blade blank and fit the handle scales yourself, and even making a sheath yourself. You can do it for half the price of the pre-made ones, and it's one of my most-used knives.


If you're wanting to buy a knife that can both be used alongside a folding saw and hatchet, AND be able to be the only tool you carry for processing firewood, then you're going to need to buy a larger, full-tang knife. I think that the Ka-Bar Becker BK7 is a good choice for this. They're easy-to-sharpen because they're made out of 1095, and they work pretty well. They can be used for chopping (especially if you put a lanyard on it and hold it by the end), and for smaller stuff.

But I think the best knives for the money are from Varusteleka- particularly their Jakarripuukko and their Terava Skrama knives. They're fantastic. The Skrama is a great all-around camp knife, and their puukkos are great even if it's the only knife you carry. They're 10/10, IMO, in terms of value.

Each to his own. I just don't like how long it takes to sharpen it, and it likes to chip too, and then it takes forever to sharpen those chips out because the steel is so hard, and it still rusts at the end of it. For me, the trade-off of longer edge holding than other average stainless and carbon steels is not worth it. I'd much rather have an average stainless steel like 440c that ultimately won't hold an edge as long but won't rust, will be much easier to sharpen, and will be tougher and less prone to chipping. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2509905
I always thought the price for these apps was outrageous for what I use them for. Software as a subscription service is pretty shitty on its face, but apps like AllTrails want me to pay repeatedly for something I can get for free. Maybe someone can explain what I’m missing.

For several years my map routine has been this:
>go to CalTopo
>find a map of the area, often FS but not always
>make custom 11”x11” maps
>add waypoints, notes, etc.
>try to keep the scale as close to 1:24,000 as possible
>print them at Kinko’s for $1.50 each
>upload them to my phone

So now I’ve got custom maps for the areas I visit. If I wanted to be lazy about it, I could just download the USGS quad for free. Either way, all I’m doing is opening a a PDF on my phone that shows my location on it relative to the files interlaced GPS data.

For that function alone, a yearly subscription fee is just retarded. It’s more the principal of the matter than the actual price. Many of these apps (AllTrails, Avenza, Gaia, and the lesser known Paper Maps) used to support this function for free. None of them do anymore.

The best alternative I’ve found is Topo Nomad. It has easy access to USGS maps through the app, and allows for custom uploads. The free version allows for 5 or 6 maps to be downloaded at once. For a one time $10 fee you get a “100 year subscription” and you can store as many as you want. So basically it’s a $10 app. It also has the typical features your expect like tracking and drop pins.

So what does AllTrails have that I’m missing out on? What’s the source of their maps? How do people justify being repeatedly charged?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507989
SAD=survival mechanism
It's just your body telling you that you shouldn't bother expending too many calories because it's winter, game is scarce, and there's not much to forage.
It goes away temporarily when you force yourself to engage in a physical task. So muster the willpower to exercise every day that you need to get stuff done.
Try winter camping. But be prepared. It will force you to do stuff.
Otherwise, just lean into it. Light a fire in the stove, read some books, make a stew with beef and chicken paws so your body gets plenty of collagen to heal your tendons and skin for another year of good /out/ times.
And it is important to feel blue at times. If it is done right. Reflection is important. Going over past mistakes can help you not make them again. The idea that you have to feel "happy" all the time is propaganda to make you think there is something wrong with you.
I am not a very religious man, But look into the tradition of advent. It is basically a holiday-period for feeling somber, in preparation for the joy of Christmas. If you aren't a Christian, you could shift it to mourning the dying year, and preparing for the joy you will have in the coming year.
Thread theme https://www.youtube.com/watch?app=desktop&v=1DpdwN_0dJw
Make the next year, better than your last. You owe yourself that much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507989
leave the city whenever you can, go outside, dont cope with too much artifical light. enjoy the cold and moon/starlight.
i live in a area far more north than you and days are much shorter. when im in the city its all fake lights, tall buildings that block everything, usually wet, sloggy and raining, if it actually snows its hellish to get around. if i take the 1h drive to my parents or even better my cabin its almost no light pollution, its clear white snow, i can see the milky way or the northern light, moon shines so bright it turns night into day once reflected from the snow, its darker overall but the lightning is natural. i can spend entire days/nights in my cabin with no artifical light except whats needed to cook or hit the toiled the rest is from the fireplace or the moon and its as revitalizing as a proper summerday, not to mention the underwear errands outside to get firewood in -25c pregerably barefoot as well.
it would take me 2 weeks or more away from that to fully get the doomy darkness feel from the city, but i always find time to get away from it. even an evening drive to a parking lot away from it all can sort out my mind for the next day or two.

posts.com:
>>2503646
Crop rotation is important for soil fertility and disease prevention. If you plant broccoli year after year, your soil will get infested with the clubroot fungus. This will render your plot completley useless for growing any cabbage for 7 years.
Easy solution is to pick 3 crops from different families and then split up your garden into three fields and make sure to rotate the crops every year. Broccoli, Peas and Onions could be a solution for example.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2502953
Citrus and banana wont survive winter.

I would look into plum-apricot hybrids (pluots). If you are partial to japanese plums you will absolutely lose your shit for pluots and pluerries (plum-cherry hybrid). Look for the best pluots in your zone. If Flavor King is on that list plant two. Its that good. Imagine the best possible plum sweetness, no tart skin, with a hint of tropical fruit/banana flavor. If you can grow flavor grenade its a must. The flavor is much more mild than flavor king but its more productive, it has a long season, it hangs on the tree well. It remains crunchy even when ripe and its mostly green/yellow so birds dont bother them as much as other pluots.

For Figs make sure you get common fig and not smyrna if you dont have fig wasp in your area.

Dont plant mulberries neat concrete or structures they stain. Morus Nigra are supposedly the best tasting mulberries.

Persimmon choose between astringent vs non astringent. I personally prefer fuyu over hachiya. Astringents have to be soft before being eaten, think water balloon soft.

posts.com: Hell yeah. One of the most fun part of motorcycling is the ease of camping. This is me after firing the bike into a park that was closed for the season via the pedestrian footpath, and I decided to bring luxury as I was staying for 3 days and brought a tent. Normally, I sleep under my cover - I bought a dark green ATV cover for the cruiser, as it has enough space underneath it to cover the bike fully while also allowing me to ground sleep underneath it. This time, I wanted some comforts, and turns out a 6 man tent will fit a decent wheelbase machine nicely. Did a few wrapped in a greatcoat under that cover while the night temperature hut freezing, which was amusing waking up with frost on the cover to then go riding down the same roads. I always have that green cover and a flat-packable woodstove in my saddlebag, just in case I feel like getting silly. Dirtbag camping is a riot!

There is no reason why Iowa shouldn't be at the bottom. The only worthwhile /out/ there is hunting, and even that's not thar good. The entire state is just corn/onions farms and cow pastures. Sure, it's "the outdoors" and not all built up with roads and cities, but that doesn't make it not shit. The winds roll through at 20-30 mph regularly, often reaching 50 mph gusts in the wintertime. This does have the benefit of making it so the snow doesn't pile up, but this also means there's jack all to do in the winter. And practically the entire state is private property owned by ornery farmers who are well within their legal right to shoot you for trespassing and they WILL do it. Granted, all my time in Iowa was spent doing surveys for scummy pipeline companies using a weird unknown law that let me onto their land, so my presence wasn't exactly appreciated. Still, unless you're fantastic friends and a local, there really isn't anywhere to go except your own property. Wanna snowmobile or hunt? Pay the landowners or you don't. Fishing? There's a few lakes with mediocre catch. And God forbid you want to hike or camp.
You couldn't pay me a billion dollars to live in that godawful state.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2501603
Not him, but here are the discrete factors that (hopefully) combine to make a good /out/ state:

>extensive public lands, i.e. state isn't covered with private property and "No Trespassing" signs (this is why Texas and Iowa in particular flunk every time)
>diverse and extensive waterways (creeks, streams, rivers, lakes, inshore, offshore) with a rich variety of species to catch, not too pressured
>diverse hunting grounds for fowl, ruminants, varmints, and preferably also big game, with reasonable local laws and regulations pertaining to hunting, not too overcrowded
>plenty of backcountry for hiking, offroading, mountain biking, primitive camping, birdwatching, nature photography, foraging, and so forth (this is partly why Alaska and Maine score so highly)
>extensive navigable waterways for kayaking, canoeing, jet skiing, powerboating, etc.
>beautiful views are a plus
>elevation is always a plus; flatland can be great /out/, it's just less likely

I believe the main reason Californians think the West Coast rates so highly is that they place far too much emphasis on beautiful views, the Grand Circle of National Parks, and the PNW. I personally love arid and semiarid grandeur, and I love the PNW, but there's more to going /out/ than scuffing boots down a trail with pretty scenery.

When filming any wildlife, it is important to approach the situation with caution and respect for the animal. Bobcats are wild animals and can be unpredictable, so it is important to keep a safe distance and avoid disturbing them. Here are some tips for filming bobcats in the wild:

Research the area where you plan to film and make sure it is a safe and appropriate location for observing bobcats.

Use a telephoto lens to capture close-up shots of the bobcat without getting too close.

Use a tripod or other stabilizing device to keep your camera steady and avoid blurry shots.

Be patient and wait for the bobcat to come to you, rather than trying to chase it or disturb it in any way.

Observe the bobcat from a distance and avoid making loud noises or sudden movements that could startle it.

If the bobcat appears to be uncomfortable or threatened, back away and give it space. The safety and well-being of the animal should always be your top priority.

I'm the guy that talked about feral cats. Like I said, you don't realize that you're replying to different posters. Do you really think that there is some huge difference between truly feral cats and bobcats? There isn't. The only main difference is that bobcats are almost entirely nocturnal in comparison to a feral cat. Even so, ferals do the bulk of their activity between sundown and sunup still. A Turkey that will fall to a bobcat will fall to a large feral cat, because their method of attack is the same. It doesn't matter how long the "spurs" on your bird are against a cat, they strike at the head/neck and crush it. Birds do much better against other animals that have a more direct and predictable approach. If you're assuming that feral cats hunt like a tame housecat, you're delusional. Ferals commit to the kill, they don't second guess or play with their food. I've witnessed it countless times.

There are so many aspects to this that idealistic kids don't anticipate, like do you have a PO box and/or official residential address (friend, family) because contact with authorities is inevitable and you need someplace to call home for taxes, car insurance, driver's license, etc. Not a vanlifer, but extended road trips give you a new perspective on many things, like how truck stops (Loves, TSA, etc) are a national treasure for a man on the road. Wet wipes and alcohol hand sanitizer have many uses and are essential for contact with civilization. Cell coverage/internet are spottier than many would assume outside urban areas. Temperature inside the vehicle while sleeping is one issue, but HUMIDITY control can be an even bigger problem. Also, I've found AAA to be well worth the cost when far from home, you can't rely on the "kindness of strangers" like we used to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I actually tried van life for a while and I still go out with my van once in a while.

I actually liked it as I had a job that only required a few hours of internet connection per day and not much else so I wasn't tied down to anywhere and could just travel. Longest nonstop journey I did was from Hungary to Holland to Switzerland in a big triangle over the course of 3 weeks.

It was comfy and very free although there were some very obvious downsides only a few days in:

1. Maintaining proper hygiene quickly becomes a challenge as there's no comfortable solution for bathing, shitting, pissing, brushing teeth, etc in a small space like that. I resorted to sponge bathing from a 40L barrel with baby soap which only worked for 2-3 days max before the water in the barrel got grosser than anything I was washing off. I had a portable toilet in the car for the other things, works fine but you gotta live with your one tiny ass room you eat and sleep in smelling like shit and piss constantly.

2. Gas is real expensive now days so even with my old job the lifestyle is unfeasible until things change.

3. You quickly find yourself ostracized from society because you are functionally a smelly homeless person. Dating long term was a non option as any girl I got along well with to invite to my house saw a white van instead and understandably changed their minds. The life style changes you into being a smelly homeless man whether you want it to or not. The concept of "socially acceptable behavior" becomes foreign to you after just a few weeks of not participating in it. Trust me. The wandering gypsy got it's reputation for a reason.

BUT. If you don't care about being an absolute menace to society whenever you stop for snacks at an Aldi and already have a partner interested in the life style, Id say try it out. Its fun at least for a little while and you get to see a lot of cool /out/ish places.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2499405
Its a trade off, if you don't like society and don't want to ever positively engage in it again then van life is for you. If you still want to go to the bars/clubs in the city some weekends or enjoy the comfort of a room larger than the interior of a microwave then its probably not for you.

Some examples: While visiting Amsterdam I got so used to just bathing in any body of water I saw, that naturally I did what many in that poor town full of water would consider a disturbance to the peace.
Whenever I got tired I just laid down on the sidewalk in fetal position even. Cashiers likely died inside whenever my mongoloid looking ass walked into a gas station in boxers and a pair of worn out moccasins.
One of my most fond memories from this time was getting pulled over twice in the span of 15 minutes in Switzerland for being mistaken for an immigrant van. After which I hid in some logging clearing entry way (to avoid further harassment) and promptly ran out of water and ended up climbing a cliff face dehydrated and basically naked at 9am to drink from the worlds smallest water fall as the wet moss and cold water consumed my body. Leaving back to my car covered head to toe in mud and bruises but with a two litre bottle of dirty Alp water and a smile.
(Pic not from same place but sorta similar)

I lived out of a van for a few months, without a job, and I distinctly remember how weird it was losing track of time. In the normal world, I was constantly keeping tracking of time
>time to get up
>time for lunch
>time to go home
>time to cook dinner
>time to watch tb
>time to go to bed
But when I had no schedule, and was living more-or-less outside, time became completely irrelevant. Instead, all I cared about was daylight.
I really miss the simplicity of it all. Sure, it was uncomfortable, but it was simple and with that simplicity came a sense of peace.

>>2496241
"Van Life" is best enjoyed if you have some reason to travel in order to make that way of living worthwhile. The convenience of living rent/motel free means that a 3 month trip becomes a lot more achievable to those with only a couple grand savings.

Driving a van is a bit of a PITA and you will want to do short hops from town to town and do a bit of exploring, then rest up overnight and go another 30mins/hour down the road and explore that place, or do whatever.
Great if you're travelling to rock climb every major spot in the country, or surf every good beach, go to every national park or go to every Six Flags ect. You kind of need a directive to make the most of it.

As a permanent way of living it is one step departed from living in a motel or a tent.
If you are intending on doing it for a cheap existence and not a holiday then go find a homeless community like Slab City and live there in your van because that's the true permanent living solution. You won't run into any issues with squatting there.

If you have a job, rent a place because the benefits far outweigh the money you save living inside a 3x2meter box.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507246
Propane heater, either a Mr Heater radiant cabinet heater (what I use living in Canada) or a little Martin one. Use a CO alarm with USB rechargeable 9v batteries (separate) and don't run it while you're asleep. Heats a small space plenty even with a window cracked.
Get a good sleeping bag rated for lower than the lowest possible temps in your area and make sure you layer up on blankets & clothes, night cap and all. And keep your calorie intake up on colder nights.
Also, if you can, insulate your sleeping/living area. Even if it's just a mylar blanket attached to the ceiling and some plastic over the windows, it's better than losing *all* of your heat every day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503222
Anyone can “sail”, but it takes a lot of practice, experience, and knowledge to be good at it. I own a Catalina 22 (probably a little smaller than the boat in your pic) and it’s super easy. Is there wind? Raise a sail or two. Is the wind too strong? Drop a sail or reef the main (essentially just pulling the sail down a bit to decrease surface area). No wind? Use the engine and cruise around.

Be prepared to spend a chunk of cash yearly after your purchase, especially if you keep it on the water as marine fees can get pricey, but a small/mid-sized Catalina is no where near as maintenance heavy as people in this thread are saying it is. Mine’s been on the water for a year now and all I’ve had to do is tighten a few screws and clean the boat from time to time. There are numerous boats at my marina that are practically abandoned but are still afloat no problem, they just look like shit.

A Catalina is a great place to learn to sail, but be aware that getting a boat that size is gonna come with a steeper learning curve than going out on the water in a sailing dinghy, a Hobie Cat, or paying for lessons.

Overall though, sailing is a 10/10 /out/ activity. Don’t let the basement dwellers who larp as hikers scare you off.

>>2503222
Sailing (as in, letting the wind propel you) is not hard to learn. If all you had was wind, and flat water all around you, it wouldn't be hard to "sail".

But it's not like that. You have islands, underwater rocks, buoys, other boats, rules, currents, wind drift, weather, and you can't stay at sea forever. A boat never "stops", you can't hit the brakes like with a car. It's all real-time. Navigating, maneuvering in ports, mooring... that's harder.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503264
>thousands a month on a 30'er
Are you sprinkling it with gold every evening or something?

>>2503222
It's not that hard. Go out on a calm day with like under 10 mph winds. Learn the draft of your boat, study the charts of where you'll be sailing, go out under engine and get a feel for how it handles.
When you feel like you're getting the hang of it, head into the wind and hoist the mainsail. Unfurl (unroll) the jib. Cleat (fasten) the sheets for both, the jib sheet on the leeward side (opposite side of where the wind is blowing from). The easiest way I can explain this is that if you are turning to the left, the jib sheet on the left side needs to be fastened and vice versa. Turn in whichever direction you have some space.

For starting out you'll wanna let the sheets out until the sail starts luffing ("dancing" in the wind), then sheet them in a little bit until they stop luffing. Put the engine into neutral and be taken aback as the boat keeps moving forward powered by nothing but the wind.

Try tacking. If you are sitting on the windward side (the side the wind is blowing from) which is common practice, push the tiller away from you. If you have wheel steering, just turn into the wind. The mainsail will take care of itself but the jib sheet will need to be released from the side it's fastened on and pulled in/sheeted in on the opposite side.

I'd recommend either seeing if you can find someone more experienced to go for a sail with, either on their boat or yours, but it's not mandatory as long as you keep the boat manageable (30ft is definitely manageable) and start out in benign conditions (I'd say under 10 mph winds, preferably around 5 mph).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
so belay jacket is mostly a marketing term for a set of features - mainly lots of down, cut large to fit over all other layers, designed for sedentary activity... basically this is what you put on in between higher output activity. they are also usually not weatherproof as they are expecting to be used only well below freezing. getting one as your do everything for cold weather is definitely not what they are and you'll probably be disappointed in what you purchased.

saying that if it's what you are looking for the only real thing you have to look at is the total fill weight - not fill power. generally fill weight (with 800ish power) can go into these categories: 2-4oz is warm sweater, 5-9oz is legit winter, 10+ is expedition/artic levels. i'm guessing your "normal" down jacket is closer to that sweater weight as that's what most people actually need and are willing to pay for. after finding fill weight you can decide on other features like how durable, weatherproof, total weight, hood...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508405
Belay jackets aren't marketing. It works. Way better than layering more stuff. I climb in a thin jacket and feel great and just toss on my belay jacket when I stop. More layers under a shell will just make you sweaty while you climb and cold when you stop.

Black Diamond Belay Parka is my go to. Yeah its bulkier and heavier than down for the same weight, but its super cheap (can find them on sale all the time) and super durable. Doesn't care about tears or rips or getting wet.

>But if its cold enough for snow then my down won't get wet

Yes it will. If you are covered with a dusting of snow or ice and put your jacket over it, it will melt and be absorbed by the down. Any sweat as well. After a couple days of using it like this the down jacket will be a lump of ice.

Steve house has a short article about it. Essentially, synthetic parkas are super low maintenance, which is what you want when shit is bad. Down is high maintenance and should be reserved for cragging or other done-in-a-day missions.

Now if you just want a jacket for more causal use, the yeah the Marmot guide down jacket is the best value.

It triggers me to see woodland BDUs un-pressed and un-bloused. Blousing is when you use a small piece of rounded elastic band with a hook on each end to tightly roll your BDU pant cuffs to just below the tops of your boots, and also tie the laces around the boot (if needed) to shorten them, and tuck them away, often under the blousing.

You can also use a velcro strap and a slightly different method.

Blousing and tucking are minor skills that you should learn if you wear BDU pants, because they're done for reasons other than just looking sharp, such as heat retention in cold weather, keeping dust and gravel out of your shit, and not getting your dangling homeless person laces caught in a shrub and then sliding face-first down an embankment.

Basically, if you wear BDUs like a 1990s skater wearing his JNCOs, you're doing it wrong, just like that faggot last month who broke his $450 ultralight pack because he was too dumb to use the hauling strap to put it on, didn't even know what it was.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>sportsmans guide
Always a shit show regarding their sizes and quality but often good prices and a wide assortment. Site can be a slog to go through but plenty of reviews.
>sukonka
Not surplus but uses surplus russian wool blankets to make some of ghe cheapest wool coats.
>kommando store
Literally made by /k/ autists. Usually more expensive but digs deep to find stuff, sorts the good from the bad, and has a good refund policy if an issue arises. Also has great autist food and sticker/velcro gear. American Varusteleka in my eyes since both have a sense of humor. Their emails are actually pretty funny.
Theyll bring in like rhodesian boots and carrying vests or recently had the chest rig from heat made.
>keep shooting and colemans
Usually both have a good variety of surplus that is either sold or you wont find elsewhere
>swiss link
Used to be real good for hard to find but their warehouse burned down years ago.
>british sites off top of head
Mean and green
Military mart
Army surplus warehouse
Surplus and lost
Asmc
Forces uniform kit
Surplus and outdoors
>swedish site
Cant find the name anymore. Started with an S but had a lot of old swedish stock on it. I consider british, swiss, and swedish some of the best designed (british) or built (swedish and swiss) crap out there.
Most the supply tends to be hoarded in england and us. The southwest us where there isnt much inclement westher has massive warehouses that store this stuff that goes on auction each year where you see this surplus goto vendors. I think Arizona. This was talking to a surplus shop in my area albeit each year local surplus shops tend to carry more chinese repros than surplus like rothco.
>ebay and etsy
If you know what you are looking for like west german wool trousers, look at these websites as they sell a lot of dead boomer stock that wouldnt sell at goodwill. Good to use a site like sportsmans, read the views on the article and then price shop.

I had one. My advice should be taken with a heap of salt since I'm a goofasaurus.

The frame.

I like to keep packs high on my back and close to me so maybe this is my fault but the frame made my shirt ( worn underneath the same jacket this pack would have been issued with) constantly ride up.
Also, the frame is uncomfortable. The two lower points managed to bruise my lower back.

>>2483680

Varusteleka's attempts at humor are hit or miss. They've actually reined it in a little since a few years ago, when they had some real fedora'd edgelords on staff. But humor aside, the super-detailed descriptions are great, sizing info is helpful, photo spreads are nice, website is well organized and enjoyable to browse overall. Also I trust the reviews, because I've seen some pretty scathing reviews stand for years, even for their house-brand items. The prices for used items seem reasonable from what I can tell, and shipping isn't too bad. (PROTIP: If you care at all about delivery time to USA, spend the extra $5 on DHL.)

But for first-timers, be advised that Varusteleka sells a lot of Mil-Tec chinesium trinkets alongside the Euro milsurp and quality new items. Not necessarily a bad thing (it's cheap), just FYI.

no, mate. it doesn't work like that.

an ultralight pack won't stand up to constant abuse, particularly bush whacking, but that's not the intended purpose. they are for thru-hikers doing 20-35km+ every single day for weeks or months on end. in that scenario, it makes sense to cut every gram of weight possible. nobody is purchasing them to cart around 10kg worth of gear. if you do that, you're a dumb ass.

> throwing gear in the trash after one hike

not true. I'm still using ultralight gear that was bought years ago, and has remained in great condition.

what gear is appropriate depends on what you you're doing in the outdoors. camping? inexpensive, heavy gear or milsurp is fine. multi-day hiking? probably better to go lightweight. thru-hiking? ultralight. it's not difficult to understand.

Good week for mushrooms ahead edition

>Community-based tools for IDing and Cataloguing
Mushroomobserver.org
The Bolete Filter: https://boletes.wpamushroomclub.org/
Inaturalist app (directly draws data from mushroomobserver but is itself a more generalized platform)
Google Scholar: Massive resource for papers and studies regarding current clinical and indigenous uses of medicinal fungi.

If you expect to get a remotely meaningful ID here, you need to be taking photos of the mushroom as you found it, on it's substrate, a clear shot of the top and side view of it, and a clear shot of the gills/pores/stipe/stem or otherwise the entire undercarriage of the mushroom. every detail of the encounter helps, where, when, what was the weather, etc.
If you want people who do this for a living to give their guess on ID's, take all of the above and make quality observations on Mushroomobserver.

This science needs as much redundant ID and loacation data as possible, any observation has value and is a meaningful contribution that takes a few more seconds than just taking a picture of the pretty thing you saw in the woods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2506039
>How can I make mushrooms to proliferate in an area so the following year has a larger amount of them?

The fruiting body you see on the surface is just one small part of the fungi. Beneath the surface is a mycelium system that spawns the fruiting bodies in an area that consistently produces mushrooms. I assume the best way to proliferate a desired fruiting body is to first proliferate mycelium growth (maybe by spreading nutrient substrate around the area), or to spread spores over the desired area during ideal weather conditions and over an ideal substrate in ideal locations to promote growth (ie under a damp log or on moist sheltered leaf litter during a cool rainy season, dependent on species). Both methods are dependent on local weather and light conditions, because they are done outside of a controlled environment. Large colonies also take a long time to grow and cover a large area, there are many examples in both the eastern and western US of colonies that are hundreds to thousands of acres in size and they are estimated to have taken hundreds to thousands of years to attain that much area. Might be worth a try, I'm not an expert.

>>2506113
i've never done anything but innoculating directly into pre-sterilized injection port bag of either millet/milo or rye, shaking up the bag once there's colonization, and then repacking it into a block. and just open up the grow bag for o2 when it's colonized, they'll fill the entire empty space on top of the block with fruit.

that's the best way to do low-sporulating strains as far as i've ever heard, if you try that with golden teachers or otherwise high sporulating strains you're just going to have a thick layer of spores on top of the block which is begging for contamination before a 2nd flush happens

point being the first flush is literally 99.99% guaranteed unless you somehow injected contamination in with the spores, zero stress zero doubts, zero equipment, just substrate bag and spore syringe.

if you're so inclined you can throw the colonized grain in with your choice of tub substrate mix if you are specifically trying to get 2-3+ flushes, it's still the safest way to get colonized grain in the first place.

>>2495136
>young zoomie here, my mother is deathly afraid of me hiking off the beaten path because she's worried i'm going to get murdered by someone with a weed plantation
>is she being overly paranoid or is this a common thing in appalachia?
I'm almost 40 and have been trekking the backcountry of Appalachia since I was a kid: fishing, hunting, or just hiking. At the very most, I might carry along a muzzle loader during late fall when bears are fattening up for winter (and in case I see a deer and have bought tags that year), but I've never needed to use it to defend myself.

I know some folks who know some folks who are moonshiners, but have never stumbled upon a shine still nor a weed plantation in all my years stomping through them there hills. The odds are fairly low; there are millions of acres out there.

Your mother is suffering from JMS (Jewish Mother Syndrome) and is simply generically worried about you straying from the nest and doing anything that might not be completely, 100% safe.

Learn to navigate if you're going anywhere you might get lost, stay inside during the winter unless you know what you're doing, don't drive 2WD import sedans down gravel access roads during/after bad weather, keep an eye out for Cletus's private property signs, and you should be fine. If in doubt, go armed (read the firearm regs for state lands, National Forests, etc.)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2496477
Really almost anywhere I've gone in PA I've found good food. Perhaps I have been preconditioned to like our food since I grew up there, but everywhere I went I found good food. If I'm in an unfamiliar area I'll ask locals for good pointers. I can personally attest that western PA has the best food in all of PA. Any city along the Ohio river has good food. New Castle has good food(see: Pizza Joe's). Franklin has good food, as well as a lot of those towns up there in the Allegheny National Forest. There's good food to be found around the mountains, but in the sparsely populated area west of Altoona and Altoona itself, there's not much good. Eastern PA has good food, but not as much as Western PA. Try those out-of-the-way bar/restaurants in the backcountry around the mountains, they have great food. I guess it's knowing where to look.

You truly have no idea what you're talking about, not even slightly. The great majority of rhododendron-choked Appalachian waterways and surrounding areas are virtually deserted, with a dinky town or two distantly nearby.

And animals... I once walked through some woods near Radford, VA to a lake known as Claytor Lake to go catfishing, and turned on my headlamp. Everywhere I looked, I saw eyeshine, a galaxy of it. Raccoons, opossums, and deer, mostly, I'm sure, but probably others. It surprised me because Claytor is so developed.

In Appalachia, herds of whitetail deer graze their way through some small towns. Black bears rifle through trash cans on the regular. Coyotes steal chickens, cougars take stray dogs, squirrels throw nuts down onto your head and car, eagles, hawks, ravens, owls, and songbirds abound... ducks, geese, even herons can be found everywhere.

You haven't got the slightest clue. One of the main themes of Appalachia is the scarce population and abundant wildlife.

>There are 25 million people in Appalachia.
As long as we're consulting Wikipedia, the entire Appalachian region is 205,000 sq. mi. with around 25m pop., as you say. California is 163k sq. mi. with around about 37m pop.

This means that California has around 227 people per sq. mi., while Appalachia has around 122 people per sq. mi. In other words, Appalachia has around half the population density of California; and, like California, Appalachia's populations are heavily concentrated in cities.

The heart of the Appalachians around the nexus of TN, VA, WV, KY, and NC is very sparsely populated and stuffed full of wildlife. I named only an obvious few rather than consulting Wikipedia to dispense an autistic list like you just did.

>>2496881
>mostly desert
There are more than 4,000 species of plants in the Sonoran desert and transition zone of Arizona alone that are known as of the time of this post (this number is for example, over 500 species higher than the known cataloged vascular plant species of NY state). This is not counting fungi or lichen species. It ranks 3rd in the entire US in this metric at the time of this post. More are discovered every year. AZGFD manages over 800 native non-insect animal species. Over 1/4th of AZ is temperate forest, only 2/5ths is true arid.

The largest known fungal colony specimen in the world (also possibly the largest living "animal" in the world) was discovered in OR (Armillaria ostoyae), the largest and possibly oldest clonal tree specimen in the world was found in south-central UT (Pando). The largest and highest scoring trophy Rocky Mountain Elk to date have been consistently taken from AZ (1st in total specimens and highest scores) and UT (2nd, but first if measuring number of trophy Elk per sq mi area).

The climate of every western state is more varied in every measurement than any individual eastern US state. The topography of every wester state is more varied than any eastern US state. The amount of public and ironically even private land in every western state is higher than the amount of public and private lands in every eastern US state (east of the Mississippi), due to the size disparity of eastern and western states.

The restaurants in Northern PA are mostly unexceptional. Some exceptions:
There's a place in Bradford called Kabob's that totally exceeded my expectations. Some of the best Med food I've ever tasted. Never would've expected that in Bradford.
The Summit restaurant on 219 near Ridgway has outstanding bar food (burgers, wings, ribs, all that).
Alfie's, a shack in Erie, have some of the better wings I've had outside of Buffalo with unique sauces.
Freeport Landing (North East) and Moe's (Coudersport) had decent food at honest prices, but no longer exist.
Primanti Bros is always good for their cheese fries, though their sandwiches are hot trash.
I have yet to have a decent pizza anywhere in Pennsylvania, or Ohio for that matter. I'm sure they exist somewhere. They're just harder to find.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Also have a story about weird banging noises. I'm not the best at green texting so I shall post reddit style

I bought a one tigris backpacking tents a couple years ago, one of those tents where it's just a sheet of polyester, you provide the poles and rope. Anyway, I was hiking, desperately looking for flat ground in order to set it up and had luckily found a nice little clearing off the trail and past the treeline. By the time I had that gay tent up, it was dark so I went back to my bag to rummage for my headlamp. While I was in my bag, I started hearing this metallic banging noise, kind of like someone hitting a homerun with an aluminum bat. I was spooked because I am absolutely certain I was no where near any sort of private property. I kind of just shrugged it off as another camper set up not too far off, not usual but not impossible. Well the noise started getting closer and louder and the closer and louder it got, the more adrenaline that started to pump into my veins. Of course the noise was now in the immediate vicinity so I cut my headlamp on and aimed it towards the source. On both sides of the tree was the silhouette of a massive creature, extremely wide and tall. I fucking SHIT myself. I froze and couldnt breathe. The silhouette urked around the tree and into the light. It was a bloodied US Senator John Fetterman bashing his forehead into every tree he passed. He muttered good morning and then something about fracking and then continued on into the treeline as if I wasn't just standing three feet away from him.

Absolutely terrifying experience, I don't hike without a gun now.

My first encounter with spooky stuff in the /out/doors came when I was a wee lad
>Be me, camping with my family in North Wales
>campsite is a small family run place that my family has been coming too since my mum was wee
>After lights out I go to explore the camp (this was pretty usual for me)
>There are several fields, one of which is relevant here
>The dogwalking field is a field with long grass and a path running around its border. On one border there was a small wooded stream and myself and a few other children would cross the narrow but deep portion that bordered the field to play in the broad and shallow section in the trees by the fence that marked the edge of the site. There is some light from the main house, and from a couple of streetlights at the other edge of the field that illuminate the little country road
>I decide it would be cool to see what it looks like at night and head on over for the gap we used to cross at
>As I approach I feel my back prickle but brave through it, because your a dumb shit when your a wee lad
>I reach the crossing and something feels off
>I look up into the trees above the stream
>2 green eyes shine back at me, like cat eyes but bigger
>I hear a snarling from the trees
>panic.avi
>Run screaming back to my mum and dad who dont believe me
>Dont go exploring at night any more that holiday
It would be over a decade before someone would tell me about the Big Cat cryptids of the UK, and I firmly believe thats what I encountered that day
>Be me, teenager, at school camp in the lakes
>sat outside our cabin with the others around a fire
>Suddenly we hear a rumbling noise
>Rumbling comes towards us, and passes underneath us
>Everyone looks at each other in confusion
>Teacher makes a joke about tunnel fires
>Everyone shrugs it off and goes back to eating
>Dont bring it up again
To this day I do not know what that was. We never spoke of it after that

>>2495553
I might have, this summer gone. I walk a lot at night in the summer as its too hot for my Northern blood to still enough to sleep. I was walking through what I roughly worked out was its territory (more of that in a sec) and something big began to snarl and bark at me from uphill. I dont think this was it though, it didnt sound as big. Probably a fox, although it kept on at me until I left the area.
As to the territory, I figured it out, ironically, earlier the year I encountered it. I was walking through there and suddenly started feeling really afraid. This is really unusual for me as im pretty confident and I know the area like the back of my hand, plus the dark doesnt scare me.
Anyway, I had been feeling oddly nervy as I approached the area, but I didnt understand why. The feeling grew until it hit hard. I felt like I was being watched, hunted. The mist didnt help, but it was weird. Im not used to feeling like that, especially in such a local area. I kept going until I reached the bridge. I considered crossing and heading to the fishing pond to sit like I sometimes do, but I couldnt shake that prickling down my back and the fear, so I turned up the path I was on when I saw the beast, a week or so later, and headed on up and out of the park. The feeling died off as I passed the old building I was planning to explore for the challenge, and had all but faded by the time I reached the old visitor centre only a hundred or so metres further. Based on this I had a rough estimation of the Northern most extent of its range. I also thought I saw 2 red eyes in the mist across the vale, but that was probably my imagination.
On a side note I saw a UFO nearby last year.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2496329
>fingers on the hull
Back when I was 16 - 18 I attended Myerscough College. Along the back theres a river, and upstream a weir that ran into a pool on the far side of the canal bridge. We used to go bathing up there, and it was fine when you were with people, but it felt wrong, not in the naughty way but in the creepy "something is not right here" when alone. There could be people on the other side of the bridge and it would still feel off, but it really became scary when there was noone around. I did dismiss it initially as just nerves, maybe some ancestral fear of still bodies of water which were opaque, as primordial predators could lurk in them. Anyway at one point I found a kayak that had been washed down by the floods, and my class and I played about with it up there. Nothing really happened with other people, as I said, and we used to paddle around the pool (it wasnt deep, you could wade through it. 4 - 5 feet at the most I would say)
A couple of times I went up there on my own with the kayak. Now, we had all swam in the pool, and it was empty. There where NO underwater objects or protrusions. Shit, I waded through it. But when you were up there in the pool in the kayak, alone, you would hear noises, as though underwater twigs or fingernails were scraping on the hull. It was really creepy, and I used to get nervous about even paddling with my hands (we didnt have a paddle).
To one side - the lower in the picture - there is a cut away in the concrete basin for some vents or drains of some kind, and that always made me really nervous, even a little fearful. I pushed myself to wade to it once, and look at it, but I couldnt bring myself to step into it, even though it was relatively shallow compared to the rest of the pool.
If it was just me I might have dismissed it, but it wasnt. A few classmates also mentioned that the pool was really creepy when alone, and that they had also heard the scraping too.
Pic related, its the pool.

posts.name: YouTuber demands rescue helicopter, has a complete meltdown
posts.com:
>On Nov 15, 2022, around 5:20 p.m., Idaho County Dispatch received a call from the International Emergency Response Coordination Center. They had received an SOS from a Garmin Inreach device belonging to Jonathan Conti, videographer/YouTuber, of Boise. The location given was just north of the Walton Lakes, which is south of the Powell Ranger Station, between the Elk Summit Rd (Forest Service Road 360) and Tom Beal Park Road (Forest Service Road 362).

>Idaho County Dispatch used the link provided by IERCC to message with Conti. Conti stated he needed rescued as he had snowshoed in, but had dropped down into a canyon that he couldn’t climb out of due to the snow being too thick. He had food, water and shelter and was safe for the night. He had parked his vehicle on Elk Summit Road about five miles from his location and was not familiar with the area, but told dispatch that he could make it to Walton Lake if that was a better rescue spot.

>On Nov. 16, 2022, Idaho County Sergeant Keith Olsen and Idaho County Deputy Stan Denham responded at first light. Idaho County Dispatch advised Conti to head to the Walton Lakes Trailhead, which was about half a mile from his location, and gave him coordinates to where he could be picked up by the deputies. Idaho County Deputies left the Powell Ranger Station by snowmobile on the Tom Beal Road. They cut numerous fallen trees out of the road to get to the Walton Lakes Trailhead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>During this time, Idaho County Dispatch kept sending Conti messages with directions on how to get to the trailhead to meet the deputies and Dispatch continued to get responses from him stating “What are you talking about?”, “I feel like I should wait at this lake,” “I need someone to come get me at this lake, that’s why I called for a rescue.” Dispatch urged Conti to get to the 362 Road and to go slow and steady and take his time as there were no alternative options. Conti advised he wanted a helicopter because walking out was impossible as there was five feet of snow, and the trail was gone. Dispatch again urged and explained to Conti how to get to where he would need to meet the deputies and that it was not possible for a helicopter to land on a frozen lake.

>Deputies could only get so far by snowmobile as they hit a rock face and would need him to hike up to meet them. Conti replied, “Fine, but I feel like I’m walking to disaster.” Conti then walked about a third of a mile in the wrong direction before going back to Walton Lake and sending a message to Dispatch at about 12:45 PM stating that he had stopped to set up camp as he was out of food, out of energy and was scared.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>With this information, deputies left the trailhead and hiked down to Conti’s location which was approximately half a mile in approximately two feet of snow. Conti was found to be in good physical condition with no injuries and still had plenty of food and provisions in his backpack. Deputies helped Conti gather up his camp and walked him to the trailhead. He was taken by snowmobile back to the Ranger Station where the deputy’s patrol vehicles were parked, and then given a ride back to his vehicle on Forest Service Road 360.

Haven't posted ITT yet. I'm none of the (You)s that the rest of (You) are arguing with.

This unprepared, inexperienced wimp is a YouTuber who set out to make money by recording himself engaged in survivalist activities in the woods during the wintertime. That makes him 1.) a public entertainment figure who 2.) was out in the woods in a "professional" capacity.

Because of this, I find it entirely acceptable for the sheriffs, the general public, YouTube users, and everyone else alive to ridicule him as a fool. The world needs more ridicule to minimize stupid people doing stupid things.

As a matter of fact, in my opinion the state shouldn't be obligated to rescue anyone at all. I never even implied such a thing. I don't think it's okay to waste search and rescue resources at all, no matter who you are. If you, a private citizen, end up needing rescue, you should call for that rescue; but you should also feel ashamed of yourself, learn from your mistakes, and not overestimate your abilities moving forward.

The guy in the OP who needed rescue made himself a public figure, for profit, and the situation he needed rescuing from was the very same one that he created for himself in order to turn that profit. For this reason, it's okay for everyone to ridicule him.

>>2508038
>There was a woman that died like half a mile from the trail and no one was able to find her for a month, despite her staying alive
This is why I tell people on this board to learn to use a topo map and base plate compass if they plan to leave sight of an established trail.

It bears repeating: You can get lost just out of sight of an established trail, and a topo map and compass have infinite battery life. To make best use of those old-school tools, you do need to keep track of where you are as you hike in at least a general sense, but even if you don't, at least with the compass you can follow a heading or bearing, even if you can't manage to estimate or triangulate your precise position on the map.

Without at least a compass that you know how to use, you can't reliably head in any direction at all as you'll veer off-course. You may die. You can learn to use this shit with a Google search and some practice, so do it.

>>2504957
>Im confused about what im looking for, do i want back country skis, touring skis, cross country?

If you just want to tour and are not interested in making Alpine descents then you want cross country skis. Specifically, backcountry touring x-country skis. They will typically be wider than fits in a groomed x-country track but they will/should have metal edges that handle a wider range of conditions and terrain- but they will still be double cambered so you still kick and glide like traditional x-country...this is the perfect ski for sking up ungroomed trails and forest service roads and exploring relatively flat terrain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Paulides is a greedy boomer, but I also think he that he unironically believes the shit he's saying and that It's not just some act on his part. I don't really have much of an opinion on Bigfoot, but I will say that I did find Les Stroud account interesting. He said that he heard hooping and whooping noises akin to those of a chimpanzee that were coming from just out of sight, beyond the tree line, and that when he reached for his camera, whatever it was went crashing through the woods in retreat. He said it sounded "like a locomotive." So, what the fuck was that? I do not believe that he was lying. He had absolutely no reason to lie about something like that and it's only hurt his career and public image overall. I think he was telling the truth. So, what could that have been? It had to be a very large animal to sound "like a locomotive" as it crashed through the forest. What's big enough to do that in Alaska? A bear and a moose. That's about it really, and neither one of those makes ape-like whooping and hooping noises. This one little anecdote all by itself is fairly compelling to me because, as I said, I simply do not believe that he's lying. The only explanations for this are that either there's a Silver Back Gorilla escaped from a zoo that's running around in the remote forests of Alaska, or it was some kind of large, unknown apelike creature, which sounds a lot like Bigfoot to me.

I think the supernatural thing makes more sense than a real normal giant ape.

This is based on a few things in the past couple years that changed my mind:

First is Skinwalker Ranch, there’s a lot of bigfoot talk with that, but it’s all sorts of crazy supernatural stuff. The TV series is pretty cool but I wish it was more of a doc and less of a reality TV show.

Second is listening to those old Navajo Ranger dudes. Check a video of them. Both guys were sheriffs on The Rez for decades and they don’t have the stigma attached to the stuff and they’re real straightforward about bogfoot stuff going along with UFOs.

Third and the biggest one is Les Stroud. He really didn’t want to become “The Bigfoot Guy”, but if you listen to him on Rogan and a couple other interviews after his Bigfoot hunt season, he admits that the one time he had strange happenings, there was more supernatural stuff that went along with it. Hey guys!

I just purchased a 54" #60 traditional bow with 7.4 GPI carbon arrows that have 100 grain tips preinstalled with all the required accessories. A client at work also brought me 3 styrofoam targets that are taped up for free. Also purchased 6 fixed 100 grain hunting tips. posts.name: Anonymous

>>2504004
I think you need years of practice to hunt successfully with a traditional bow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2504004
>What are some tips/experiences for practicing for and actually hunting deer in the winter with a trad bow?
Since you weren't brought up hunting, you need to find a mentor who was. Taking the shot is in many ways the least important aspect of hunting, although you obviously must be able to make your shot in order to seal the whole deal.

What will you do with your deer once you've shot it? Have you ever field-dressed a deer? Can you drag or carry a whole (or dismembered) deer to your vehicle, then secure it properly?

This is both a tip, and my experience. Get a mentor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2504004

You need this grouping at 30 yards, consistently hitting a kill-zone sized target every draw, for starters.

But, as >>2504133 said, taking the shot is the least important part of hunting, it's the one second in your hundreds of hours of work.

Finding a mentor, or mentors in my case, was what actually made me a successful hunter. Old timers love telling you all about how to hunt, so if you let one of them bend your ear for a bit you'll learn a lot.

To catch up on local deer gossip I swing by the auto shop and talk to the old timers who hang out there, for whatever reason.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2504004
There is such a thing as too much practice. Fatigue breaks down your form before you really feel tired and can fuck with your head. Your 4" group will turn into a 7, and you will get frustrated. Dont let it go to your head, put it down and try again tomorrow.

I started shooting again in the spring after not firing a bow in years and I was perfectly confident on big game out to 15meters by mid summer, and by deer season I was comfortable at anything under 20, If you practice consistantly?hunting next fall is an easily attainable goal. You will want to practice for a few months at least.
if you must hunt now get some judo points, go for small game and stump shooting as often as you can. It is a huge help in getting your range estimation and confidence down, I havent had a rabbit, squirrel or grouse run off after being hit with a judo, even a bad hit.

practice practice practice. also, arrow weight and F.O.C. are the most important aspects in hunting with trad bow. once i started taking those into consideration my accuracy and passthrus starting getting impressive. look into the "traditional bowhunting" yt channel. he is smart and a good teacher, all of his advice i followed so far hasnt let me down.

if you practice often with trad bow from now until next fall you will def be a good enough shot by then to take a deer. practice religiously and practice as much as you can with your hunting setup (broadhead attached etc).

buck fever is a real thing, you will wanna be close for your first shot. once you are confident in your hunting try to take further kill shots. once you drop the sumbitch the fun part is over and the hard part begins. tracking and hauling the fucker. you will learn this the hard way if no one is there to help you. if you have a quad or side by side you are set. buy a good bright light for this, and carry 2 spares, along with marking tape.

idk what else to say, just general tips.
>if its a buck in rut, hang him at least 5 days
keep a sharp knife and even a spare
>always ALWAYS poke the fucker to make sure he is dead before approaching, prefably the eye. the smart ones play dead when they know they are dying and will try to gore you before they die. not common but it happens, happened to me
if he is alive, and he is weak just approach from underneath his neck and not above (in range of the antlers) and slice his throat while holding his antlers very tightly just in case. if he is strong he will prob just make a break for it, but if not just pop him another arrow so he wont run another mile and a half.

i didnt get one by bow this year but heres my rifle buck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2504209
>No you don't, if we're talking about shooting practice. You can become good-enough archer within weeks or even days.
This is absurd. First of all, it will take you at least a month to be able to work your way up to a poundage that you can hunt deer with and shoot with it comfortably, without risking injury. If you can't do a 30 minute continuous session without getting tired, you're not strong enough to properly control your bow even on your first shot.

Second of all, being able to hit a flat, stationary target with a marked bulls-eye consistently from 7-10 yards while standing with perfect form and posture has very little bearing on whether or not you'll be able to hit a dear in the wild. You need practice with 3d targets and you need to do dynamic training, such as shooting from different positions/angles, with objects in the way, changing distance etc. At the very least you need to have consistent groupings at 20 meters, not just 10. Because you're far more likely to get a clean shot from 20 meters than from 10. Anything much more than 20 meters and you're probably better off to just not take the shot even if you're an amazing archer because the chance that you'll just injure the deer is too high.

>The hunting itself is the tricky part
yes, this is true. once you become a good archer, becoming a good hunter is still a huge hurdle. you have to become a better hunter than a rifle or compound bow hunter simply because you need to get closer to the target.

As for OP: Learn how to hunt squirrel with your longbow. A squirrel is a much harder target to hit, but they're a lot more frequent and give you good practice. It's kind of like training with weighted clothes. Once you can hunt squirrel reliably, hunting deer will be much easier, since you will have all the confidence in the world to hit your target, and it then just becomes a matter of finding the deer.

Anon if you have a PhD in engineering and you can't afford to ski then you either aren't making anywhere near what you could or you have terrible money management. IDK what to tell you, but ski mountains are quite busy.

Budget for a ski season:
Boots: = $500/5 seasons = $100
Skis is same (buy used), so another $100
Poles = $50/5 = $10
Jacket, $200/5 = $40
Pants, $200/5 = $40
socks, helmet, other personal items: $300/5 = $60
Season pass: $800 (your mileage may vary)
Assuming you drive 90 miles to go to the resort and gas is $3.50 and your rig gets 30 MPG: $10.50 * 2 (because both directions) * 20 days/season = $420

Total: $1570/season. Sorry you're poor anon, but frankly if you can't come up with $1570 dollars for a ski season then that's your problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
feel like first aid kit is pretty specific to your activity and risk tolerance. don't buy a kit and assume it will cover everything you need, usually there is a ton of stuff in there that has no practical value and too little of things like moleskin which might actually make your trip enjoyable. here's my thoughts generally:

annoying injuries - stuff like cuts, blisters, headache... are pretty common and not trip ending. most of this is pretty easy to treat too so it makes sense to bring with some little bandaids or meds to make the trip less miserable if they occur.

trip ending - these are less common and not life threatening but serious enough that you would be unable to continue with your activity. mostly this is the falling over category where you end with broken bones or larger cuts. most of this isn't immediately life threatening but requires more care than you can do in the field. your goal here is to provide a way to self rescue back to somewhere you can get better care, splints and gauze/quickclot are the big items here and depending on how big your risk for this is can either be dedicated equipment in your kit or improvised from your other gear.

emergency - this is stuff you are actually going to die from and usually there isn't a ton you can do for yourself in this case. if you are in a group it makes sense to bring some trauma kit to help stabilize but solo your best bet is to seriously consider the risk and either adjust or avoid the activities that might cause these kind of injuries if the risk is unacceptable. this is also the category you would start carrying some kind of PLB for as the best you can hope for is to stabilize the situation and then hope rescue comes before death does.

medicine - a few pain meds, a few asprin (heart attack), something for alergic reactions, and any prescription is really all you need. this is ignoring any specialty stuff like for high altitude sicknesses or opioids for self rescue.

>>2503526
Would you really want to operate on yourself for that? A serious pneumothorax demands a syringe/tube through the ribs. Although it is an urgent situation, you can still function for hours/days after it occurs, unless it's a tension pneumothorax (rarer). So you'd typically still have time to call/find help.

In critical situations though, like tension pneumothorax or a pneumothorax in combat, syringe/needle kits can be used. They're pretty cheap.

Not sure if this will help - something weird with my 2 pneumothorax a few years ago is that I'm almost certain they were caused by or have something to do with dehydration. After they happened, I felt small pains and was out of breath faster whenever I wasn't drinking enough water, immediately went away after reminding myself to properly get enough fluids.

Even if you have massive trauma on a limb, blood will still flow in and out, assuming the artery is still somewhat intact. If you put pressure on the limb enough to close of the veins, but not the arteries, the blood will pour into the limb but not out. Think of a ring on your finger that is too tight. The finger will turn red and swell up because blood gets in but not out.

>the tires on my 4x4 are over $2000 a set, wear out fast on pavement, gets 8mpg, sketch to drive over 50mph. i ain't going shopping in that thing. i have to take off the mud tires if i want to take it that far on the highway.
That's true enough. I won't even take out my deep-cleat trail runners unless I know the cleats will be properly utilized, rather than just worn down. Also, if I'm hiking long-distance to a stream, I'm going to either carry my wading boots with me, or else swap the outsoles from felt to tread and back again (I have Korkers with swappable outsoles). Thankfully, montane streams in the Appalachians stay warm enough that I can wade in felt all year round.

But yeah, while your logic is good, the fact is that REI is also filled with casual dayhiking tourists, or yuppies, as they were called in the 1980s. I don't even mind so much that urban and suburban fleas want to see the real Earth sometimes, but I do mind worshiping the golden calf (megacorporate America, China) by overpaying for trendy brand-name sweatshop gear. This is coming from someone who owns a fly rod that's worth more than your 4x4 tires.

I buy used/secondhand, 100% American, handmade, or handcrafted as much as I can, and it's often fine. I just got back from Goodwill with a very nice super-thin camo rain jacket for next spring, and a very nice sportsman's coat, for $20 + tax. Don't seem to have actually been used.

But gentlemen, the real reason to visit thrift stores (if you fish or hunt) is to snag little pouches, organizers, boxes, and bins. I fill a cart with those sumbitches when I visit. Pic related, a brand-new belt loop + clip pouch with mesh pockets, tool/strap attachments, zippered pockets, and a drawstring top. Perfect for mycologists as well as sportmen. Beside it is a dense little pouch that's fairly wide and perfect for carrying a fly reel, even has a belt loop in back and small dividers/pouches for leaders etc.

What you can see in the pic cost ~$10.

>>2495730
The slings on cams are color-coded for ease of use when placing (example: red is #1 size in BD, yellow is #2) and this is helpful for strenuous routes to know a size of cam at a glance and generally looks professional. 3 companies I know of use the same color scheme — BD, Wild Country and DMM. Metolius has their own color scheme and they are nuts. I don’t even know their color/size scheme by heart. It’s wildly weird.

As for runners (extendo-slings!), double and quad-length slings, there is no set standard of length-to-color ratio. It’s really just manufacturer dependent, but they are so interchangeable and can be clipped together to make longer lengths artificially that it doesn’t really matter as much as you think. You will know what size sling you are working with based on how you racked up and by the volume of the stowed sling itself.

You can educate yourself, you know. It’s not 19 year old Susie’s job to tell your ass how it all works off the shelf in an REI. She just wants to get some more stickers for her Thermaflask man.
