posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
How do you guys keep yourself warm during the night when winter camping?

Some of my friends and myself will build a self-feeding fire outside of our tents, sometimes using the 'log-jenga method', and sometimes using the method where large logs fall down a frame as the logs at the bottom turn to ash.

Whereas other friends I have will have a fire in the evening, but will then rely solely on their clothing and sleeping bag to keep them warm, but still keeping tinder, kindling, and processed logs in their tent if they get too cold and need to build a fire quickly in the night if it gets too cold.


How do you do it? What clothes do you wear in your sleeping bag? What other measures do you take to keep yourself warm during the night and what do you do to prepare in case the night is colder than you're expecting and have to warm yourself up quickly?

I'd be very interested to know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I suppose it almost goes without saying but having a proper, temperature-appropriate sleeping mat is a must. If I'm really cold, I'll light a single candle in the tent. It's surprisingly effective. Just keep an eye on it. I run warm so, even when it's freezing, the most I'll sleep in is long johns, a baselayer, and a midlayer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508711

Be careful with the candle method. It can burn a hole through these modern material tents real fast if positioned poorly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508711
This is fantastic advice. I've seen friends complain that they're freezing and they don't understand why because they have down sleeping bags, fleece coveralls, and all of these thermal underlayers, but then they just have a standard foam mat to sleep on instead of having an appropriate mat.

I've never heard of someone using a candle for warmth. That's actually really interesting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508718
It's a very effective, convenient method for warming a small space but like >>2508717
said, you've got to be careful doing it. You could easily burn your tent down. I've heard some people will cover themselves and the candle with a blanket - or similar - creating a kind of teepee inside the tent with your head acting as the pole. That 'inner tent' becomes much warmer, much quicker and the heat is then trapped at the top of the blanket (which is easier for you to monitor) rather than risking burning synthetics in the tent roof. You have to be aware of CO poisoning of course.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508703
Eat enough food and hydrate. Digestion will increase body temp, water is needed to keep your blood volume up and warm blood circulating. Don't touch metal or nylon bare handed if possible. Ideally don't even stand unprotected. Stand/kneel on a sitting pad or reflectix mat to keep your feet warm when you're not moving.

Just before bed if you have the fuel or a fire heat up some water, put in a sealed stainless or nalgene container, wrap it in something and use it to pre-heat your bag. Do a couple jumping jacks to warm up before getting in the bag. Basically decrease the amount of time spent warming up your own sleeping bag. Emergency wise I have a space blanket in all seasons and usually a handwarmer or two.. I avoid the vapor barriers because they quickly become sweat traps.

>>2508711
>>2508718
If you can double layer sleeping pads, ideally put a closed cell one on top of the air pad. Nylon gets weird below freezing, closed cell rubber is more comfortable against the body. If you feel cold despite the r value being apparently good enough, try even just a 1/8thin neoprene mat.

>>2508703
double up on your sleeping mats: one closed cell foam then an inflatable on top. use a roomy down mummy bag rated for colder than you expect, sleep only in dry baselayers including a toque (not the ones you've worn all day, have a separate set for sleeping in). wear a pair of loose, very high loft thermal socks. drink some hot chocolate and eat some trail mix before bed. fill a naglene or two with hot water and use them to heat up your bag before you get in. use an old gatorade bottle to piss in so you don't have to get up in the night. candle lantern or isobutane lantern that you can hang up so it doesn't get knocked over

posts.com:
Multipurpose Tool Edition

Feel free to post tobaccos (no weed allowed), pipes, collections, pics of favorite combos for going /out/, pics of what you're doing with your pipe and any questions you might have.

Want to get into smoking pipes without spending too much cash?
Get a corncob pipe and a pouch of either Captain Black or Half and Half tobacco, available at most drugstores.
What you'll need: pipe, tobacco, lighter or matches, pipe cleaners, and either a regular old nail or a pipe tool (combination tamper, scoop, and small pick).
All of these together should run you less than $25, still. God help you.

Having trouble keeping your pipe lit? Fill it with less tobacco and smoke it slower than you think you need to, lightly tamping as needed when the smoke starts thinning out.
If you're still having trouble, try filling your pipe this way:
https://youtu.be/0XHYPso7TXs

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2498523
Meerschaum and morta are good too. Pipes made from other types of wood besides briar and morta can be sketchy. Some woods have oils deep inside that can be toxic. Generally you’re safe unless your pipe starts burning through the bowl, but it’s still better to be safe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2498529
Well, cigarettes generally use low grade Burley. There’s also usually hardly any tobacco in a cigarette, meaning you taste burning paper and low grade Burley. However, Burley is a type of pipe tobacco, but it’s usually the highest grade Burley. Burley used in a pipe tobacco blend will typically have notes of cocoa, nuts, and sometimes brown sugar. But there are many other different types of tobacco used in pipe blends; you can have Virginias (Lemon Virginia, Red Virginia, Stoved Virginias, etc.), which often have a fruity, citrusy, earthy, grassy, and tea-like flavor. You can have Perique which is only grown in Louisiana bayous and cured in logs and has a very spicy and plum-like flavor. You can have Dark Fired Kentucky which is a type of Burley that is cured over burning wood, giving it a kind of smoked BBQ and herbal flavor. You can have Oriental (Yenidje, Izmir, Bosma, Drama, Smyrna, Samsun, Xanthi, Katerini, etc.) which comes from the Northeast Mediterranean and the Levant, and usually has an herbal, incense-like, and spicy, very fragrant flavor and aroma. You also have Latakia, which is the most important component in “English” blends and is a type of Oriental that is fire cured using aromatic woods from the Middle East, giving it a sweet, smoky, and incense-y flavor and aroma. It used to come from Syria (Latakia, Syria) up until the Syrian civil war, so now it comes from Cyprus while still using the same techniques as Syrian Latakia. In general, all of those types of tobacco have very strong flavors, which is really the point of pipe smoking, as opposed to the low grade Burley in cigs that tastes like burning cardboard. They don’t use flavorful tobacco in cigarettes because people smoke them for the nicotine, not the flavor. There was a point in time last century when luxury cigarettes did contain Oriental tobaccos, but that stopped when cigarette companies realized smokers were more concerned about nicotine than flavor.

I remember one encounter with a wild boar in the woods when I was starting out.

I was hammock camping. I found a nice place without any high bushes and with trees that were just perfect distance from each other to hang my stuff from. Grass looked like there was an old, forgotten hiking trail there. It's something common here, so I didn't worry about it and set up my tarp and hammock.
Late at night, when I was just chilling and smoking I heard steps and breaking of twigs. Sure enough a fucking boar was getting closer to me - I set up my camp not on an old trekking trail, but on a trail made by wild animals. It was constantly grunting while I was just lying there terrified. When it got close enough to almost touch my tarp it started loudly sniffing. Then it loudly snorted in clear disgust and left.

Thank god I didn't move or tried to scare it away. Later I learned that boars when frightened are more likely to attack than to run away. Smell is a good way to deter wild animals. Not being a complete retard that sets up a camp on animal tracks and trails is also a good idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I may be dumb because apparently this is already a thing, but packing rubbed out flake really loose makes it burn so much better and taste so much better. I was having problems with flakes before because they would constantly go out and taste like ash. Then I started packing it really loose, and it improved so much. Come to find out, most people already loosely pack rubbed out flake. So if you have problems with flakes going out or not tasting great, pack them super loose. Gravity fill it, lightly push it down just to the halfway point, gravity fill again, and use the fleshy part of your thumb to make sure everything is in the bowl, BUT DON’T PUSH DOWN. Do a char light, use the weight of the tamper to even out the charred tobacco without putting any pressure, do another light and tamp it the same way, but you’re not done yet. After tamping it a 2nd time, the tobacco should be down to the 3/4 mark of the bowl. Do your true light and it should be good to go. Packing it looser means the bowl won’t be filled, but because flake tobacco, even when rubbed out, burns slower and expands, you’ll still get a good 40 minutes in a regular sized bowl. It’s actually those characteristics (slow burn, expansion), that make it smoke terribly if you pack it tightly.

>>2503448
Longer stem = cooler smoke.
That being said you can get cooler smoke just by smoking more carefully, I imagine they're a pain to clean properly, they're easy to damage, and they are ridiculously overpriced.
Sure, they are a bit of a meme, but I'd still love to add one to my collection - it must be comfy sitting in a chair with a good book and a pipe that you can hold while keeping your arm on the armrest.

Historically churchwardens were popular also because:
- clay pipes often had long stems, because you were supposed to snap off the end to keep it more hygienic - as far as I know it was a common practice in taverns, where guests could borrow a pipe from the innkeeper.
- expensive pipes were a symbol of status and longer stems gives more room for artisans to show their skills.
- you can stab someone in the eye and kill them :^) [ok, just joking, but historians did found two such cases]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2505113
It sounds like it's moisture related. I have used nording keystones at the bottom of my pipes ever since I started smoking and I never experienced irritation or tongue bite. Along with sucking up some extra moisture they create a nice little void in the bottom of your bowl and it is easier to completely smoke your tobacco down to ash. No dottle. They also protect the bottom of the bowl from getting too hot as well. I use them in all of my pipes, even cobs so I don't scorch the bottoms. Also, I clean and reuse them. I usually get 3 to 4 smokes from a stone. I throw them away once they are all black. Worth a try. A big bag is $10 from most places. I've been on the same bag for 2 years. I probably average about 5 bowls a week to give you an idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm currently as off the grid as is legal for my state/county (which means I need to be hooked to electric but never use it just pay the monthly minimum hookup fee or whatever).

We have multiple gardens, sheep for wool/meat, goats for milk/meat, chickens for eggs/meat, and pigs for meat. I also hunt all fall/winter for meat, fish during the summer when the days are long.

We only have 10 acres so need to buy in hay and feed, which we cover the cost of by selling pig, lamb or goat whole or half shares.

I spend pretty much all my time out of doors when not at work.

I support a family of four on one salary.

Well for water. Solar panels and batteries for power.

it's about building codes/minimum standards for dwellings more than anything.

i'm guessing mostly it's the fact that jurisdictions haven't really caught up to living offgrid. there really should be a variance for these types of dwellings. if someone wants to buy some land and build their house, install septic, etc etc on their timeline, that should be their right. no one is going to buy a fucking house on a plot of land and then realize "oh shit, it's not on the grid, fuck me, i didn't bother to see if there was electricity!"

like my county (lane, OR) has minimum dwelling sizes, septic/mains/well requirements, etc etc; which make it either outright impossible to buy land, and build a homestead from scratch, or make the permitting/siting process take so long that construction loans aren't feasible. For example: getting a conditional use permit for a dwelling on F2 land requires at least 18 months of paperwork and waiting around while some 25 y/o nitwit planner looks for reasons to deny your build, meanwhile construction loans typically have a 1 year conversion timeline. wife and i lucked out and found a property that already had the CUP on it, otherwise there was no way we could have swung the land purchase and rolled it into our construction loan.

it's such a fucky situation, one that a lot of the naive 20 somethings here completely fail to understand. then again if it were as simple as rolling an RV onto a plot of land and going for it, there wouldn't be any countryside left. Some states are probably more amenable to this kind of thing, but the overall trend seems to be to make moving out into rural areas more and more difficult -- environmentalism gone wild coupled with a subtle/backhanded mommy government hatred of proles and independence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2505999
Sure.

We do seasonal pigs here. That is, we purchase feeder piglets from a local farm in the spring, and then they go to the butcher in the fall. We do this specifically to avoid overwintering pigs and dealing with full grown breeders. It's a lot less work on our part and we don't carry the burden of the breeding stock.

Because of this we have a 1.5 acre forest pasture rich in acorns for the pigs to live on. They shop up when they're young and easily handled. Already cut and weaned. We purchase pig feed from a local feed mill that has very reasonable prices and sources somewhat locally. Pigs handle the feed well and grow quickly. We only usually need to deworm them once during this process. As the weather is mild they generally don't need much housing. They destroy anything you give them anyways, so their run in always looks like shit.

We keep 2 for our family and sell the other 3+ which pays for all 5+ pigs every year. Essentially we 'eat for free'. We sell half shares of pork to friends and locals who buy into all the buzzwordy meat stuff. This is why they go to a butcher, because there's some regulations there on how meat sales and preparation are handled. I send my two along as well because our butcher does a much much better job than I do and the pork sales cover it 100%, so why not.

People want to eat meme breeds so Berkshires are very popular, but hybrids are generally more vigorous and less likely to fail to thrive. Berkshire crosses is what we generally handle here.

In a small operation, this is the most cost effective and easiest method by far. Every year we look into buying a male and two females to start our own breeding program. Planning on keeping 5+ piglets and selling the rest, but the cost of everything skyrockets and piglet sales alone won't cover all the costs, so the operation starts operating at a loss and my goal is always to break even on food.

There are many different accessories that can be helpful when fishing from a kayak, depending on your specific needs and preferences. Some common accessories that many kayak fishermen like to have include:

A fishing rod holder to keep your rod secure while you paddle or fish.

A fish finder to help you locate fish and other underwater structures.

A bait bucket or cooler to keep your bait fresh and store your catch.

A paddle leash to prevent your paddle from floating away if you drop it.

A dry bag to protect your belongings from water and keep them dry.

A waterproof map case to keep your maps and other important documents safe from water.

A kayak anchor to help you stay in one spot while fishing.

A waterproof flashlight or headlamp for fishing at night or in low-light conditions.

A landing net to help you safely bring your catch aboard your kayak.

A kayak cart to make it easier to transport your kayak to and from the water.

It is also important to have all necessary safety gear, such as a personal flotation device (PFD) and a whistle or other signaling device. Make sure to check local regulations for any other required gear or permits.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few other things that I've thought of that you may need.

>A VHF radio if fishing in areas where coast guard and rescue authorities can be reached by radio
>A dry suit or wet suit if fishing in cold water temperatures. You dress for immersion, not air temperature. May not want to be wearing cotton if in a cold water kayaking situation. Your body loses heat much faster when immersed in cold water than it does when dry. Cotton clothing retains water and accelerates the body cooling when wet. You want to go with synthetic fabrics or wool are generally better choices.
>A net is most definitely a must
>A stringer for keeping any fish you want to keep. I just purchased a large stainless steel fish stringer loop but you can use any cheapo stringer and just tie it somewhere on your kayak.

A bivy is a waterproof sack that your sleeping bag slips in. They often have a little hoop or pole so you have room around your head. You probably don’t want a bivy.

I am in the same job situation. Now 35. Staying fit is quiet easy. By that I mean maintaining my fitness level.
Maintenance takes me maybe 4 hours per week. If you are out of shape you will have to invest considerably more time to get back to baseline.
- Maintain "hardened feet", and baseline cardio: for example: Rucking / Hiking 2 or 3 times a week even if its just 60 or 90 minutes.
- Maintain mobility and baseline athletic strength: Knees-over-toes program, or some Yoga + calisthenics (45 minutes twice a week)
- Maintain good posture: Fix your posture. Most people have terrible posture. It will take a lot of effort. (10 to 20 minutes a day)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Your windows are shit, and most likely the largest source of heat loss.
First you need to make sure the seal around the frame is airtight.
Use some caulking to do this.
After that you need to create more panes.
This can be done with cheap plastic film, typically polycro, but if you don’t care about seeing through the window, you can use cheap Mylar emergency blankets since it’s also reflective.
Do not tape these directly to the glass, tape it to the window frame, and make sure it’s tight so there is a small air gap between the glass and the film.
If you really want, you can then made an additional pane by taping film across the wall’s cutout the window frame is set into.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2509469
Do this for your bedroom, and seal the HVAC vent in that room too if you have one.
I’m guessing your bedroom door doesn’t have a seal.
Rubber weather seal for doors is cheap and has adhesive to stick right on to the frame.
Don’t seal the bottom of the door unless you wanna suffocate.
After that, just an electric tower heater you can put next to you will probably be fine

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2509417
Concentrate primarily on warming yourself. Once you have a large space a single human body is only going to pump out about 100W or so of heat, if there's wind or a lot of surface area transferring heat it's a losing battle.

As for creating a smaller, insulated space, cardboard, styrofoam, and blankets may be a good option. For the cardboard to work what you want is a layers with something like styrofoam or loosely balled up newspaper in-between to create dead air. If you can get something like Reflextix that will also work great to create walls as it's basically aluminized bubblewrap and has great insulation. Cardboard also provide something stiff enough that you can basically build an interior space. Put yourself in a corner, make two walls and a ceiling. You can heat it but be very careful as a lot of these budget insulation materials are very flammable.

>>2509182
It’s hard to get statistics on this, because most attacks don’t happen in any kind of wilderness. It’s usually dogs, which are found around people.

Are we talking severity, likelihood, or what? Because bees can kill some unfortunate people with a few stings, and there’s like a billion bees in the US. There are also plenty of sharks in the shallow waters of the Gulf Coast, and lots of swimmers. I’ve seen a few, and one time I saw what was either a huge barracuda or a piece of drift wood like two feet away (I ran instead of staying to investigate).

The South has alligators, and when I was young and stupid I tangled with them on three occasions. Twice because they needed to be removed and once because it was funny. They were small but the smaller ones have more energy.

Supposedly feral hogs are dangerous too. I’ve run into pigs dozens of times and they always just run away, sometimes streaking like I was out to get ’em. I don’t believe the “sow with piglets” thing either, as I’ve seen sows trample their children to escape. But they’re pretty big and could definitely do some damage.

There are 5 species of venomous snakes in my state (technically 7 but 2 don’t count). The only ones you’ll generally see are water moccasins/cotton mouths, which are everywhere. Copperheads are everywhere as well, but they’re very tame (I’ve stepped on one and he just slithered away) and their venom is very mild. I mean, it’ll probably fuck you up but not as bad as a rattle snake or coral snake.

I’ve heard that there are a lot of deer attacks but that must just be a short seasonal thing. They always run away. Plus hunters go looking for them, so that probably doesn’t help.

>hog gets wounded

Pretty standard.

Did you guys know that sounders are almost exclusively female? Males are only found within the group when they’re adolescents or when breeding. Pigs have a heat cycle like dogs rather than a breeding season like deer. The sounder is led by a matriarch, who isn’t always the biggest, or the oldest, or the strongest. Some researchers think they might be chosen by intelligence, but no one really knows. Plus, how would the dumber pigs know the leader is intelligent? Sounds like hog wash to me. The males get run out of the group (which is called a sounder, but you knew that, or figured it out by now) when they reach adulthood, and are generally solo, but will team up with other males, forming friendships and small groups of their own. Of course these are wild animals so competition for food and territory may come into play between males, so the male sounders are often much smaller.

This has been Pig Chat. Tune in next week when we discuss false charges and wallowing habits.

>>2496456
Historically, they used to burn much more often and even more severely naturally. It's astonishing how much folks forget things from even just a century ago and even more so how easily data and media can be manipulated to fit it to a desired paradigm. The takeaway is that wildfires were, have been, and always will be a natural feature of the western US and that folks needed to plan and prepare for them rather than try to eliminate them. Part of their natural function or result was to recycle, replenish and renew forest nutrients often allowing them to regrow with even greater biodiversity at their climax until the next cycle hit. Anyone living in a naturally fire prone forest should be aware of this.

Tent. Bivvies are too condensation-prone, and they're cocoons, so there's no escape from contacting the material.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2504576
I started a MeetUp group years ago, from the ground up, at my own expense (it was $20 a month to host the group). It lasted for a little over two years (hard to say really), and had just over 120 members. We were going in two trips per month, so it was pretty active.

The demographics of the people who join those groups don’t exactly line up with the people of /out/. It was mostly women over 30 and men over 50. Many of them are severely lacking in experience. Eventually you get to know the group members, but at first it’s awkward. You’re spending days with strangers, from sun up till sundown.

Groups are a completely different dynamic than solo hikes. You always move slower in a group; someone is lagging, maybe hurt, people stop for the bathroom at different times, some need more breaks, some are slow starters in the morning… it’s just how it is. They also feel compelled to talk; it’s human nature to engage when you’re next to someone for that long. Also finding a spot large enough to accommodate everyone can be a pain or sometimes straight up impossible. Oh, and everyone wants to vote on stuff, and democracy is a sham (“yeah we should keep going to find a better spot and not stay at this perfectly adequate one. What? No I think the sun will be up longer than 30 minutes and we’re sure to find an even batter campsite just over that next hill/around that next turn. Let’s vote in it.”).

It can have some perks, like multiple cars and people who know more than you (inb4 “no one knows more than me”).

Oddly enough I never really clicked with anyone in the group. I’m a pretty social person, so I had fun on the group hikes, but I never kept in touch with any of them. And after dozens of group hikes I can safely say I prefer going alone rather than with casual acquaintances.

Thanks for reading my blog. Be sure to subscribe.

posts.name: VostokHeavyIndustries
posts.com:
>>2496990
>How did you get into patch making?
Randomly one day Badgerhounds aesthetic tank guy design was the image on the 'Popular Threads' thing on the 4chan landing page. I kept monitoring the /k/ thread whilst it was being worked on and found it interesting enough to keep hanging out after it was released. I had a go at designing my own one for a group of friends which was a painless enough experience I figured I would have a go at making one to sell. Picked up an image in one of the threads that a few people expressed an interest in seeing become an idea and then have just kept going and slowly expanding.

>Is it profitable?
I make a profit on it but it's not enough to do as a full time gig. I don't know how the bigger sellers like Aho and Badger find things but I just treat it like a hobby. I'm basically making enough profit to be able to afford the next drop in a reasonable amount of time.

>What kind of machines do you use?
Nearly all the sellers you see on 4chan use third party companies, primarily in China, to manufacture them. So you create the design send it to them along with requests for production (number of, embroidered/woven, type of backing etc), they tell you if any changes need to be made. Then, once all confirmed, in a week or two you get a parcel full of patches.

There are a couple of exceptions. 19kenny84, who makes very small batches by hand and Twilry who has a website connected to a machine but that's been gone a while now. You can find sellers on Etsy who will do one offs for you, they seem to be generally in Eastern Europe. These will tend to cost more than a generic patch because it's a one off but it's an option.

>Also, does anyone have an archive to all the patch sites?
A list with me on it.
https://hackmd.io/@Patchboi/PatchThread

A list that doesn't include me.
https://patchfeed.com/patch-seller-list/

TL;DR - petch

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507765
>rains means 100% humidity
It doesn’t. It often means the relative humidity is over 90%, but not always, especially in places where rain is caused by high altitude frontal systems rather than localized evaporation. And we see the former in places that have low humidity most of the year (the western half of the US).
>why have a tent if it’s not going to rain
Incase it does rain. And where are they more likely to get unexpected rain storms? At high elevations, mostly found in the western half of the US.

it does actually. and definitely where it counts ie the tent wall. the raindrops saturate the air with water vapor. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2505811
A hone creates micro serrations that, essentially, saw at a very small scale. If you hone and don't wash your blades thoroughly you are usually adding chromium (an ingredient of stainless steel) to your food--which is toxic and causes cancer. There is zero reason to hone or strop on the trail... you aren't chopping tomatoes or skinning fowl.
I keep my home cutlery sharp after, I never hone and can skin a tomato easily.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507477
Based chinkposter. I don't think it would really help. Hunger is a hell of a motivator, 99% of human beings out there would also be willing to eat dogs or cats if they were close to starvation, even their own pets. You might get a little advantage by being the first one to start eating them before they have all been killed by other people, but not a lot. And eating grass doesn't really help, we can't get much nutrients from it.

If you're really well off and concerned about this type of thing, focus on material preparations. Buy beans, rice and dry pasta and seal them in airtight food-grade 5 gallon buckets with something to remove the oxygen and moisture--ideally silica gel packets but hand warmers work if you don't have those. Food stored that way will keep for many years. Also, get vacuum packed heirloom seeds, and pick up some gardening skills.

I'm curious by the way, what do you mean chinese feudalism? Do they literally have serfs and barons out there or is it like a metaphor for everyone being poor and dependent on scummy landlords?

There Is a ton of info in YouTube about slingshots, they are pretty fun and a good hobby.
Making your own slingshots Is pretty fun too. If you want to Buy one, stay away from those chinese ones, search for simple shot slingshots.

>>2507055
>There are no sights with a slingshot
This Is a lie, you aim with your bands, you have to make a perfect line with your eye and ammo, your slingshot, and the target.
You will have to figure out the up/down aiming, but you get the feel of it, but there are also up/down sights for slingshots.
Aiming a slingshot Is pretty much like aiming a bow.

>>2509714
>Also any recommendations for a good wood stove?
tent stove or twig stoves?
For twig stoves firebox stoves are probably the best you can get since they are quick to setup but expensive, can try some titanium stoves from aliexpress (Lixada is good) but in my experience they are all really annoying to set up.
For tent stoves SeekOutside and Kifaru sells good ones for backpacking but for around 300usd, cant really find any cheaper unfortunately even from aliexpress.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Second cousin is dying. He has Mee-Maw's old farm land. We want to keep it in the family, but no one would be able to make payments on a $2m loan.

>675 acres rural KY
> ~200 cropland acres
> ~75 pasture acres
> 2 livable dwellings on property, one occupied (by old widow in the family, not going to charge rent)
> Farmland is on long-term lease. Lease would only cover ~25% of mortgage
> Any supplemental income has to keep the spirit of the land intact - no RV parks or logging

So far I have thought of a few ways to generate supplemental income from the land, such as
> Guide hunting (lots of white tail and turkey)
> Bee keeping (not a lot of cash in this)
> wedding venue rental (1 hour away from nearest populated area, not sure I want that many people on property)
> poultry farm (takes up pasture land space from farmers leasing)
> Air BNB/ Bed and breakfast

I am not at a point in my life where I can go farm it full time, but I am only 2 hrs away and can go up frequently.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I thru hiked the at and got went the wrong way twice and nearly got lost once
First time:
>somewhere in tn/nc
>at is constantly changing as new land is aquirred leading to old trails or dirt roads crisscrossing it, usually there are logs piled up on the wrong way and its usually well marked but not always
>take the wrong way on accident
>hike probably 2 miles
>dead ends into a neighborhood street
>pull out phone
>have reception, find trail
>end up taking a shortcut back through dense woods which was a mistake but i got committed
Second:
>somewhere in maine
>same deal, took the wrong trail
>followed it for probably 2-3 miles before it got extremely overgrown and i knew it was wrong
>no reception
>walk back
>meet another guy who also took the wrong way on the way back
>5 miles in the yellow blaze bank
Nearly getting lost:
>somewhere in nh/maine
>dense forest
>late
>go off trail about 100 steps like i always do to set up camp for the night
>wake up next morning pack up
>walk back to where I think the trail is
>cant find it
>walked far too long for this to be right direction, completely turned around
>pull out phone, no reception
>end up deciding to walk in an ever increasing spiral and hope to find the trail
>manage to find it after about 30 minutes
This was actually pretty scary, I can see how people get turned around and lost forever. My plan of I didnt find the trail when I did was to go south using the sun as a guide because I knew I would hit a road I had crossed eventually and follow that until I had reception to figure out where I was

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: One time I went up the wrong side of the mountain and nearly died. I did zero preparation or research beforehand and decided to wing it one morning after breaking camp.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are a lot of degrees to being lost. Ive never been super lost, but I’ve been turned around a few times.

>following a well worn trail
>only has markers at junctions, but super easy to follow
>trail is supposed to torn right then cross a stream
>it just sort of fades off into the woods
>turn back to find the trail
>get to it, doesn’t turn anywhere
>map must be wrong
I went back years later with a small group and we absolutely confirmed that yes, the maps (USGS, FS, and the AllTrails app someone was using) were all wrong. There is a marker where you cross the stream, but the maps show it crossing in another spot, putting you in the wrong side of another stream.

Another time
>camp just off trail, maybe 50’
>start walking to it just after breakfast the next morning, just to stretch my legs
>can’t find it
>like, at all
>I had camped very close to a short dirt road that connected to a gravel road that I’d crossed the day before
>place a very long stick up against a tree just so I can regain my sanity
>take the dirt road back to the gravel road, then the gravel road back to the trail, making a big circle
>stick is gone
Closest thing I have to an /x/ story. Sorry it’s not more compelling.

posts.com:
BACK IN THE 90s:
>be hiking in outback Queensland
>friend leading the trail
>Trail seems to be getting rough
>Friend is pressing ahead confidently so. cool we must be good.
>Eventually deadends,
>Friend goes "Oh yeah i wasn't sure about this trail like ages ago"
>He brought a map of the area but no compass
>Figured it would just be trails
>All my boy scout useless facts kick in
>Holy shit i can make a compass one second.
>sewing kit for needle
>clip on sunglasses for magnet
>leaf to float it in a cup of water.
>Compare nearby mountains on map
>Find rough location and get a heading
>Find river we were meant to be near
>Find much better, well marked path.

THESE DAYS:
>Have smartphone,
>Screenshot any hiking trails or maps in the area
>Bring spare batteries
>Don't assume friend knows what he's doing

No, I've never been lost. Cub Scouts, Boy Scouts, summer camp, JROTC (JROTC programs differ wildly; this was a good one), and the fact that I grew up hiking, fishing, and hunting saw to that.

Anyone can learn to use a map and compass in a few days, and be proficient within a few weeks/months. My only concern is that so many people have been relying on GPS for so many years now that their ability to map their environment in their heads is underdeveloped.

The stories in this thread are a great example of why I'm always telling people not to even leave clear sight of an established trail without knowing how to navigate, old-school. For all you know, some capacitor will pop in your mobile phone and it just goes dark. What then?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yeah, hiking in northern Michigan w map n compass.
Every time basically there's some access road or other that's not marked or marked totally inaccurately that throws me off.
It'd be fine if reading terrain was easy, but its a fairly flat, fully forested with poor vis, mess of undulating pots and knobs and unmarked ponds/marshes that's nightmare mode for orienteering.
Half the time I just beeline a general direction since I know generally where I'm going and would rather bushwhack than backtrack, which is sufficient since its not super wilderness and you'll hit something within a mile or two. Half the time I'm tired and just cheat with GPS.
I've never been lost more than about 300m is how I'd put it, reading those maps is challenging sometimes, so not like "lost" lost. Not sure how I'd get proper lost with a map n compass even in Michigan, never mind a backup phone. Maybe I'll find out some day..

Last example picrel
Walking along well worn hiking trail about knifepoint, headed N.
Landscape is endless knobs n pots, forested heavily, maybe 50ft vis places, 250ft at best others. Not Appalachian thick, so some vis.
I want to turn east at the access road and then south where it hits the other access road before the pond/lake.
Figuring out scale and distance is a weak point of mine in these conditions. The map is about 1.5km in width in photo.
Walking along that trail I come upon a saddle, down ENE of it is a marshy pond feature. I walk down out of pure autistic need to check it out. Neat. I walk back up, definitely the same trail. I take a compass reading, the trail continues at a 325 bearing give or take.
Continue on trail a few minutes as it curves around to a NE bearing, and come across a two-rut access road. Walk down it eastish and it goes along the north side of that same marshy pond thing I was just at, with clearcuts along its north edge.
Follow along it for a bit and... It just dies out after the marsh.
I look south past the marsh and see a hill. I walk up it and look east for that large pondlake. Eventually strike E/SE bushwhack and reach a pond. Figure its the "head" and track a SSE course to see if I can find the "body".
After a couple hundred feet I am just in the middle of dense woods getting mobbed by mosquitoes and clearly not where I thought I was.

Anyone claiming they’ve never been slightly confused as to where they are doesn’t have much experience. It happens; trails sort of fade off into the woods, or get overgrown and connect to game trails, or turn into washouts. You’d know this if you actually went hiking. “Muh navigation skills” is a massive giveaway that you’re larping, bruh. No one stops immediately when the trail is slightly less easy to follow. You press on because you’ll find where it picks up again. You know how we know that’s the case almost every time? It’s what we’ve experienced. Sometimes you don’t find it after 15 or 20 minutes, so you stop and figure it out. That’s exactly what happened both times in Alabama. The people who hike know exactly what im talking about.

I like this eno hammock tarp that I pitch on the ground. It was simple to modify. I just cut the long guyout lines down to size and sewed some duct tape grommets to the middle, to prevent sagging.
Pros:
>Provides the shelter of a tent, but little condensation when I wake up
>Packs lighter and smaller than any tent
Cons:
>No protection from biting insects - I can only use it in dry areas

>Does not stand up well to strong winds

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2508446
11ft netless Dutchware hammock with an old Wilderness Logics bug net and a Warbonnet Mamajamba tarp.

The bug net is just a tad too short, and is starting to tear. The idea behind a non-sewn net is that I have full bug protection when I’m not using an under quilt, but those times are rare, and I’m thinking permethrin would probably be enough.

My tarp is fairly old. I bought it before silpoly was common, so it’s silnylon. It’s gotten a little floppy in extended rain showers, before I had self tensioning guylines. The newer Warbonnet tarps all have beaks, which seems pretty nice.

So my next setup will be the same material hammock (Hexon 1.0) but with an attached bugnet, and a silpoly tarp with beaks.

>>2500079
>any of you /out/ists taken the offgrid cabin pill yet? howd it go?
I've been off grid for 5 years but get called a larper whenever I post so kind of gave up contributing. I bought a cheap single bedroom cottage in rural NE Victoria (australia) because it was close to a dairy farm I was managing that was already on septic and tank water. Everything works. I have a normal kitchen and office and can blare music and play video games like any other person. All my power tools are corded but the inverter has no trouble powering a pressure washer or angle grinder. A few solar panels and an inverter was all it took to take it completely off grid. Having the rain water tank at ground level is the biggest drain on my power though, every time I turn a tap there's a 50W jet pump that goes brrrr and draws the same power as a microwave running on high. Keep your rain water at roof-gutter level instead of ground level to allow gravity to keep the water pressure up so you can at least shit and shower if the power goes out. My house looks like any other 1960's Australian fibro cottage but I take a working holiday every couple of years to Taree as a cattle drover and stay in pic-related.

I want to talk about how hard it is to be green, but it really isn't. I just gifted most of my shit to grateful friends when I was 28ish and have room to move now

>>2506650
>How expensive can wood be?
We're living in a new reality these days; I've given up feeling resentful long ago.
In fairness that $7 figure includes a few tools, but it's also me cutting corners everywhere I could. You'll notice there's not even siding on it yet, inside mostly unfinished and uninsulated. Pre-covid it probably would have been around $5k. Screws were the biggest unexpected expense; If I'd borrowed or rented a nail gun I'd have saved a bit there. But then it's harder to fix mistakes, of which a beginner makes a lot.
I'm an expert scrounger of materials; if I hadn't been in such a hurry to get it built I'm sure I could have scrounged at least $1k worth of lumber from scrap piles etc. I got all the windows for free on facebook, else that would have been another $800 easy.
For reference, my shed is12x20 with a loft. A lot of people might go smaller.

>>2489351
just in case foreigners want to visit, here is a few tips for norway
>national parks
you have almost unlimited freedom going outdoors everywhere here, national parks are just more crowded and ironicly more limited. doesnt apply for all parks but no need to look for parks exclusively.
>fjords/lofoten
everyone seems to want to go there but its highly overrated and if its a travel through or roadtrip thoose places lead you away from so much else. consider if that one epic instagram pic that everyone takes is worth everything you miss.
>trails
same as parks, you can go everywhere so why go there? many trails are either the shortest route from cabin A to cabin B or they follow old travel routes that was also shortest route from A to B. rarely the most scenic or interesting. hiking here is mostly above forest limit (thats low altitude since we are far north) so finding directions is pretty easy without trails.
>camping
do not under any circumstance googlemaps campsite or camping, its not what you think. its boomers or poor families with kids cramped into small pay-per-night spots with a few accomondations like shower and toilet. wildcamp instead, again everywhere.
only time you should consider a "campsite" is if you need a shower or you want to rent one of the few cabins they often have. its not an outdoorsy experience and can be loud and crowded.
>cabins in the wild
public unguarded cabins exist but a bit hard to find and you never know if they are taken. some cabins require membership and key, some are staffed and serve hot meals. or you can rent your own on airbnb or inatur.no.
>fishing
coast/sea is unlimited
inland requires fishing license, but if no one see you no one cares... do not try it in salmon rivers their landowners are crazy and will shoot at you.
>hunting
a bit more paperwork but can be done as a foreigner on small game and birds

>why are pulks so expensive
Great question, I wonder that myself lol. Way too overpriced but oh well. I'm very lucky because I have many friends who own multiple pulks, so I've always just been fortunate enough to borrow one from a friend.
>how many km a day should i plan my trips for?
Honestly this one's up to you, I always give myself more time than necessary so that I never really have to worry about the distance. If I need two days of four days, doesn't matter. Then again I'm aware not everyone has that luxury. Generally you can travel way farther with skis on than on foot, but it's not always the case, depends heavily on the route you choose. Since you're talking about bringing a tarp you're gonna need to stay a little bit lower in the terrain where there's trees, and if that's the case you can generally speaking travel way farther with skis than on foot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2504286
I don't know what the most normal route order is, but the most challenging is from Trollheimshytta to Gjevilvasshytta in that order. So you definitely want to do it the other way around for the most pleasant and scenic route (beautiful views when walking in the Gråsjøen direction to Trollheimshytta from Gjevilvasshytta as starting point) They've also added (to my distaste) a bridge over the first major river there so if there's a lot of water when you go you will save yourself from that by walking over the bridge. From there you can either go through the valley which leads to Jøldalshytta which is a very simple hike, or take the more challenging one up the mountain, which in return gives you way better views. The last part of the trip from Jøldalshytta to Gjevilvasshytta is unknown to me, but from what I've gathered it's a reasonably simple hike, with bridges over the two main rivers there. The cabins are own by Den Norske Turistforening (DNT) so you will find out everything you need to know about the cabins from them. I never use cabins (except when I was on norways tallest mountain) so idk much about them. Have eaten a kanelbolle at gjevilvasshytta though, good shit. During the main season for hiking in Norway there's a lot of people doing trekanten, but the cabins are only open for a limited time during the summer, so you can't really get a trip alone unless you head out during autumn. It costs 70kr to drive in to the valley using some app, and it costs to park by Gjevilvasshytta. If you park by the beach (Rauøra) it's completely free, but it can be really busy,

>>2509129
It's definitely nice that you can fish without a loicence, and where fishing is concerned, Canada is at least on par with the US, if not superior.

Here in the US you have to get your freshwater licence, your saltwater loicence, your trout stamp, and your National Forest stamp.

That is per state in which you wish to fish. The exact details differ from state to state, there are bundles, and you can pick and choose, but it's still a racket, especially considering how lazy state fish and wildlife services have become and how overfished accessible areas are.

My dear ol' Dad was a lifelong fly fisherman and had planned to retire to Nova Scotia for fly fishing purposes before cancer got him.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2509332
>Atleast in ontario, you can have 3 lines if you're targetting carp with plant based bait. Luckily, catfish like my carp bait too.
In my general area here in the US, the carp in our (mostly artificial) lakes are introduced for aquatic weed control and they're catch and release only.

When backcountry fishing for native species in National Forest, I can do whatever I want even when there's official fishery classification signage posted on nearby trees, because virtually no one fishes that remotely and so the wardens don't go out there, either.

But I still follow the rules because I'm a fish hugger. I have no problem dispatching fish with a knife or rock to eat later, but I won't let them slowly asphyxiate, over-handle them, risk gut-hooking them, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2509395
>I don't think animal hair would be ideal, I would expect sinew to perform better, but that'd still be cool.
Japanese and European fishermen were known to have used horsehair lines. The Chinese were known to have used silk lines around the time of the birth of Christ, and these were later adopted in both Japan and the West; but the poorest fishermen (such as shokuryoshi) continued to use horsehair.

Sinew would have been my first instinct as well but there's probably some reason why other materials were preferred, when available. Possibly the Inuit, Native Americans (pre-contact, i.e. pre-horse), and so on used sinew or gut.

The constraints of packing food for backpacking in the cold is food freezing. This can ruin canned goods and explode jars. In the interest of eliminating goyslop from our diet, even when it could be convenient, what options do you guys use for packing up food in the deep winter?
Pasta? Rice? eggs or meat packed in bags and kept frozen from the weather?
Picture is breakfast, designed to be able to be prepared quickly in a few minutes after getting your water boiling:
[1.4 oz] Dried Oatmeal ½ Cup – 140 Calories
[1.32 oz] Olyra Fig Tea Biscuits – 180 Calories
[3.67 Oz] Nature Value Pomegranite Poptarts – 420 Calories
[2 oz] Nature Valley Fig Bar – 200 Calories
Tea Bag
Electrolyte Powder

As a side note, do any of you guys use dehydrators? I've been considering getting one for this reason, as home made chili and other things like it can be dehydrated and you have total control over your ingredients. This could also be used to prepare snacks like dried meat, fruit, and other things.

posts.com:
>>2509379
One of my favorites:

3oz shelf-stable chorizo sausage
1cup minute rice
1 bouillon cube
1tbsp tomato powder
1/2tsp Italian seasoning

The only thing you’d have to worry about is the sausage freezing, and tbdesu it doesn’t get get super cold here (the South) so it’s never been an issue for me.

All of the ingredients can usually be found in a grocery store, definitely in Whole Foods. No goyslop or weird preservatives in the sausage; only naturally occurring nitrates. Good balance of macros. Only needs 8oz of water.

posts.com:
Went rock climbing today for the first time in a while, have some questions.

1. The easiest auto belay route seems to be 5.6, is this normal?

2. I managed to do one 5.6, but the other 5.6 was too hard for me.

3. They have chalk air purifiers, but after an hour or two my throat started getting super irritated and I started coughing, and even water didn’t help. Is this normal/is there a way to prevent it?

4. Do people go rock climbing as beginners alone often? When I was trying to do the harder 5.6 and got stuck, I got kind of sad that I had no one to help me. There are also a lot of top rope routes that I can’t do since I have no partner.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2496472

1. probably, grades start at 5.7 at my gym and go through 5.11's

2. well done, muscles used in climbing arent really used in our everyday life so it'll be hard to start but stick at it and you'll progress quickly I guarantee

3. not really? you shouldn't be creating huge chalk clouds when you chalk up just enough to coat your palms and fingers inside of your chalk bag. maybe try not to breath in chalk if you see it floating

4. people boulder alone often, trick is if you see someone alone to ask if they want to top rope, most people are happy enough. its worth trying to strike up conversation with people bouldering to then organize a roped climb on a later date.

You’d be backclipped on the bolt they were lowering off. He TR’ed it, then at the bolt had to make the switch to lead. How would you re-do this scenario to be safer next time?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503108
To be clear: my understanding is that after your failed lead he was TR on his end of the rope, which was running through the QDs. So it was necessary for him to unclip each one as he passed.

The critical idea here is to never rely on a single bolt. When your partner reached the second-to-last draw, he should have clipped the belayer strand into the draw before unclipping his own strand and continuing on.

Swapping the rope in the last QD to avoid the backclip is a weird situation. I'm honestly not sure how to do that safely. I'll have to try it out on my own to see if there's a way to swap without unclipping...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503108
attach to the belay, swap lead and belay, put a quickdraw on the line if you're worried about swinging out and jump it over each clip, then lead as normal to the top.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503108
>>2503134
Just pull the rope out and let the other guy lead normally?
unless the bolt distances are far between, its much better constantly risking a 5-10m fall then having the one bolt fail and having a 30m+ factor 2 fall... Depending on how youre belaying, this could actually kill you both.

Fun fact I worked on a project with Mitsubishi heavy industry as a sub contractor doing material strain on load transfer systems as well as electrical conductivity testing for a carbon fiber aircraft design. >>2503591
The chassies are for moving air. The frame, roll cage, and everything else structural are some sort of metal alloy. Overspifying and mostly accurate: the crystal content of a material determines its strength and plasticity--the more % crystal usually the stronger a material is but it also is more brittle. An extreme comparison would be a pure iron rod and a pure diamond rod--the diamond will shatter under strain while the iron rod will bend...although it will take much more strain to shatter the diamond than bend the iron. In carbon fiber the crystal content is the graphite, which is hexagonally bonded carbon layered in a polymer. The other important factor is cyclic fatigue stresses. Over time carbon fiber will develop mocrocracking because it cracks instead of bends where metal this is much less prevent. The end result is carbon fiber can fail completely under a strain (especially in cold where the crystals cool and become more brittle) where metals will bend and distort but not fail.
Thanks for listening to my TED talk.

Buy bulk nylon straps and make your own straps for hauling gear, fastening bags, or spare rope for other projects. Get rectangular stainless steel rings for tighter fastening or heavy duty snap buttons for more creative ideas.

Wax your own cloth jacket. Get the liquid stuff you temper in water and coat any old cotton or wool jacket for weatherproofing. Beats paying hundreds for one that people don't even use in the wilderness.

Use old t-shirts or clothing scraps as extra washable wipes, throwaway handkerchiefs, even layered blankets if you have the time and sewing skills.

It was cheap 4oz ripstop off ebay. There are loads of sellers of it, often sold as kite ripstip. I waterproofed it after with fabsil gold after. it stops the nylon sucking in water when it rains.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2509287

I agree. look at online leather shops or better in person in a shop that sells leather crafting stuff. They will tell you what you need.

If it was me telling you I'd say really for starting off you need a stanley knife or thin sharp utility knife, a few needles, an edge beveler and grove cutter, a stitch marker is good for even hole marking and an awl (I like a 1mm round needle like one as it gives a nice tight hole for 1mm thick thread). I tend to use my multitool pliers if the holes are tight when sewing through thicker leather to pull the needles through.

Id say go waxed cotton for sewing first as its the easiest to use and a block of beeswax to wax your thread if its snagging, just pull the cotton over the block.

The photo is one I just took of 2 sheaths using those tools and some dye for my Enzo Trapper. Both have years of use on them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2506729
Niggas wanna be different so badly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2506771
Internal frames keep the load lower on your center of gravity so if you’re doing anything but walking down a gravel road you’re not fighting against momentum with every little sidestep. This advantage is completely negated when loads become larger. Internal frames can’t support a very high load, so the packs become wider and thicker.

People switched to internal frames when gear got smaller and lighter. Of course most people are retards and didn’t understand why, and they still wanted enormous packs, so there was a demand for very large internal frame packs.

Obviously you could use an internal frame pack with a small load and have it low on your center of gravity, but the pack itself will be heavier than in internal frame (generally).

The amount of times I've read "A lighter pack is easier to carry" is too damn high. Lower mass weighs less? Fucking incredible physics insight! Thanks, Einsteins.

Actually, though, you're all wrong. The insane cushioning and harness design on my heavy (by internal frame standards) Mystery Ranch pack make it feel 20 lbs. lighter when it's 40ish lbs.

20 lbs. lighter than what, you may ask? Glad you asked, 20 lbs. lighter than the packs made of thin plastic tarp with zero functional cushioning and minimal harnessing.

It is objectively easier to carry 40 lbs. in a Mystery Ranch pack than 20 in a Dyneema tarp sack for any amount of miles, anywhere. Why? Because excellent support, balance, and weight distribution can in fact cause 40 lbs. to place less stress on your joints and musculature and sap less of your energy than 20 lbs. in a limp plastic sack that offers almost nothing.

The last discussion I had with an ultralight fag on this board, he had no idea what a hoist strap was, and tore the wussy thin shoulder strap on his $500 brand-new Dyneema garbage bag the first time he tried to lift it incorrectly. Of course the manufacturer still sent him a replacement. After all, he was dumb enough to buy one Dyneema bag, so he'll be buying more later.

Well, I see a first-aid kit (are we all using the same Chinese first-aid satchel on this board? I have the red one), cordage, compact Gorilla tape (I carry the kind that's full-width but comes folded flat), carabiners, bug spray and sunscreen, redundant light sources and batteries, emergency blanket, collapsible water bottle(s), stove, entertainment, and all the basics that don't bear mentioning....

I can forgive the Mountain House ovepriced bullshit, assuming you have that as your low-weight, low-bulk emergency backup meals in case of emergency. If you eat only those while hiking... anon....

Also, you don't really need the meme sticks. But since they can double as tent poles and are very light, I always allow them in the "entertainment budget." I'll grant you this is a complex subject, because a stick or branch of some sort does help, or may even be vital, when traversing certain terrain. I use a wading staff while fly-fishing strong rivers, for example.

While hiking, though, if the terrain is really that bad, I go quadruped-style even with a 40ish lb. pack. If it's not that bad, I find that sticks and staves aren't needed. Then again, I don't live at the foot of the Rockies.

I'd go hiking with your stuff, although I'd drop the meme sticks in my Mom's garage at some point for her to use.

>>2505404
>well fuck me you're actually right,
I was hoping you'd just meme at me but I'm glad you actually tested this for yourself. I can reply all fucking day to you and you'd never believe me, but now you know for yourself that goretex sucks and it's way more important to me that you believe your experience than some faggot like me on an anime forum

Goretex isn't durable. The absolute worst thing you can do to goretex is to flex it and abrade it, which is exactly what happens in a shoe or boot. Goretex is less shit for things like rain jackets, but it's still a shit material that literally doesn't do what it's advertised to do, extremely delicate, non replaceable, and non repairable. Why the fuck anybody would ever buy anything with goretex blows my god damn mind.

>which material works better
this is the wrong question to ask

If you want 100% absolutely not a molecule of water getting in, wear rubber waders.
Obviously you're not going to do that. Even if you did, the moisture from your feet wouldn't be able to escape so you'd still wind up with wet feet which obviously is bad.

If you had to choose between no water getting in, and no water getting out- if you've ever hiked with wet feet you're going to know the only choice is to allow water to get out. This is less a question of material and more a question of technique and not being a retard. Rubber and plastic will keep out water, but we agree that those would suck in a shoe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2505404
>>2505427
You want to keep your feet dry while out? In order of importance:
>don't walk in fucking water.
Too many retards google "waterproof hiking boots" and think they're somehow a better outdoorsman. Nobody who actually goes out doesn't do stupid shit like purposely walking through high water.
>change your socks when they get sweaty / carry multiple pairs of socks so you can rotate them between wearing them and letting them dry
if you don't understand this then there's no helping you
>let your shoes air dry at every opportunity
take out the insoles, dont do something stupid like putting your shoes by a fire or heat source, don't do the r*ddit thing of stuffing your sweaty shoes with your sweaty socks "to keep out bugs and not lose your (one) pair of socks"
if you heed the first two maymay arrows, there will be significantly less moisture that (still) needs to evaporate out at the end of the day

Going back to your question which should be reframed as "which material works better for my specific needs," describe where you are going /out/.

Clothing, gear, everything is a compromise and is the least shit solution we have come up for a particular problem. There's no such thing as the perfect outdoor shoe or boot, only what's right for you and your environment and your level of skill/knowledge.

Goretex is terrible for literally everything

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've bought both packs to try on at home and I've noticed that many people seem to strongly prefer one or the other. What's standing out to me is that they're both like 90% the same pack.

As far as I can tell, these are the differences.

The Aether has a rigid back panel (along with a higher weight rating), heat moldable shoulder and hip straps, compression straps across the "shove-it" pouch, and a large zip that goes across the entire pack, to access anything without having to go through the traditional drawstring opening on the top.

The Atmos has the non-rigid mesh (Antigravity) packpanel (I've had problems with items poking me in the back because of this), shoulder straps and hip belt, trekking pole attachments on the shoulder strap, and a large side zip on each side to access the interior of the pack, instead of the Aether's full zip. The Atmos also has a dual front zipper pouch that isn't mentioned on the product manual for some reason. The Atmos weights 139 grams less, which is nothing imo.

Aside from those few differences, they're literally the same pack.

Oddly enough the Aether has "more features", but a lower price. I'm not sure what that's about.

I find the torso length adjustments on the Atmos dig into my back occasionally. I'm really not liking that.

For those who have tried both packs, which one do you prefer?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507754
The only thing that makes Osprey stand out is their unique suspension. The Aether doesn’t use it, but the Atmos does. And it’s not just a little quirk that makes some of their packs different. It makes an insane difference in how comfortable the pack is. Traditional flat pack panels aren’t even close to what you can get with a curved frame and a mesh panel.

I prefer the simpler design of the Exos, though it doesn’t use the specific “Anti-Gravity” system, it’s still a curved shaped with a mesh panel that creates a gap between the pack and the wearers back. Gregory makes a similar pack (the Focal) and Zpacks has a few as well (the Arc Haul series). Mountain Hardware has a few models using it too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Easiest answer is don’t buy an Osprey. They feel like cheap consoomer junk. I own a few Osprey products along with other brands. Wouldn’t buy Osprey again except the kid carrier from 5 years ago.

On the top mount bear can, I actually put my bladder in my pack brain and the bear can in the body. My brain has 2 pouches so all my personal stuff, keys wallet etc come to bed with me along with my water. Also makes it easier to fill via filter. Works great for me.

>>2501405
>These are species with thin bark that aren't supposed to survive a wildfire. Same with red cedar
Are you sure... there are/were red cedars that are 1000s of years old, surely they can survive some fire (or you're wrong about fire disturbances being as common as you think). Red cedars live long enough that their tops break off and the tree regrows from a side growth, repeatedly, forming a "candelabra". The dead, broken trunks don't rot because red cedar is insanely rot resistant, which helps it thrive in the wet PNW.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2501425
I'm not saying to cut down every last tree, especially not old growth (at that point it is better to leave it as a forest). But the truth is that most forests today are second growth ecological deserts with little to no undergrowth aside from a couple ferns. It's just a bunch of crowded fast growing trees less than 30 years old without any of the deadfall and rotting wood that supports biodiversity.
It's impossible to create an old growth forest by planting trees, it's much easier to plant a grassland and let it naturally evolve into woodlands over time. But of course that takes time and in today's zoom zoom tik tok world it's easier to plant a bunch of saplings in a grid and look like you did something.

Red maple becoming infestant in its own habitat is the result of excessive forest exploitation.
When the large trees of a climax forest are cut down in excess the forest understory is exposed and the ideal conditions for pioneer species like red maple are met.
If trees were allowed to complete their life cycle and only logged in small amounts red maple wouldn't be nearly as common. Getting rid of it also solves nothing.

posts.com:
>>2508516
nitecore nu25 and petzl actik
i have the old nu25's but the new one fixes its only problem (micro usb -> usb c)
nu 25: ultra light weight if you swap the headband. not water resistant. built in battery with short life. meant to be used in pass-thru mode with a battery bank plugged in while its on your head. great headlamp but also a great back up because the modded one is only 30 grams. doesn't feel like you have a headlamp on. really crazy winds will blow it off.
petzl actik: a lot of you guys would like this one. it uses AAA's but also has a built in battery. its still pretty light weight, won't feel it on your head much. not water-proof. great thru hiker choice.
petzl bindi: really similar to the nu25 but more battery efficient and better thought out modes. i like the nu25 hardware a bit better and this one's more expensive. good choice tho.
>>2508627
petzl's are nice regardless. that one's like a more basic version of the actik. same dual battery thing. probably more efficient since its modes aren't as bright but i'm too lazy to math. good lamp even tho its cheap.

>>2508516
At the moment I have an Olight H15S Wave, have had it for a long time. Runs with 4xAAA batteries or its own proprietary rechargeable batteries. Not waterproof and (used to be) 250 lumens. The old olight has served me well during these years, but now I have been thinking about replacing it due to cold killing it during my cycling commutes. Also the lack of red light has annoyed me every time when I have needed a red light.
The successor that I had in my mind would be Fenix HM61R, which has 1200/400/150/5 lumen settings, in addition to a red light at 5/1 lumens. It is also IP68 rated so that's nice too. It uses rechargeable 18650 batteries or 2x CR123 batteries, which is what I also use with my handheld flashlights. Having the need to carry only one kind of batteries would be nice.

posts.com: I am planning on setting up a hunting camp this year. It’s a temperate climate. Coldest it normally gets here in the winter is 20F, but it’s generally some where around freezing at night here in the winter. I have about 300 acres of private land to work with. There isn’t much elevation. It’s pretty flat. I was going to use the Ozark 11 person tent in pic related to sleep in. I was going to get a large tarp from Harbor freight to string up over the top of this in some trees for extra cover. It’s really just so I can have a porch like area to cook on a camp stove, but I think it would come in handy if there’s any heavy rain. Taking recommendations for a camp stove around $100. It does have to be light as I won’t be backpacking with it. Just sleeping there on weekends I go hunt. I’m tired of driving the 30 minutes to go hunt in the mornings. And I’ll only be leaving this up for a few months. For sleep, I was going to get a Coleman camp cot. Other stuff I’ll bring, old pots and pans, a storage truck, a cooler and a small gas generator (it’s a 1400 watt predator from harbor freight). I’m just looking to get some insight on whether this is a good idea. If I had more money I’d get a nicer 4 season tent, but I’ve camped out here in winter in my two person wenzel 3 season tent and was actually a little warm in a winter sleeping bag. Any input is welcome, especially on the tent holding up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2500949
Remnants of a bygone era... AT&T Long Lines system.
Before internet, fiber, satellites... there was long lines to make long-distance phone calls and carry TV signals.
Before long lines, there was "L-carrier", a transcontinental coaxial carrier system. This site was originally L-carrier, then upgraded to long lines, and served as a major infrastructure hub in the region before the modernization of the bell system.

This rack was part of the monitoring and alarm/notification system for the equipment on the site.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2500952
More old shit. Well-written documents done on a typewriter, signed by system engineers. 7-digit dialing, analog signalling systems and circuits, mechanical switches/relays. Interesting to read through some of this stuff, before ISO certifications and modern corporate buzzwords existed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2500965
Through the double-doors and into the battery room. 2v wet cells provided power for the equiment and subscriber loops. These batteries are why you'd still have dialtone even when the power went out. "Five-nines", etc.

Everything's dried out now, electrolyte's evaporated leaving sulfur residue on the housings and lead plates of the cells. I don't know if there's any value in this stuff, or the hazards of dealing with this much lead and sulfur outweighs anything you'd get from scrap metals.

>>2501173
>'d you do a routine checkup or why did you climb the mast?
That was an equipment upgrade and installation of 2 microwave dishes on the tower. Also did a router replacement (ran out of ports on the old one) and rebuilt the DC distribution in the rack.
I climb and do rf engineering shit professionally. A lot of the sites I work in have that fallout/urbex vibe. Some sites are real nice and clean, but those are more the exception than the norm.
Pic related is the top of a coal mill. The silos the facility used to store coal in for the boilers was repurposed as a radio site since it offered good coverage to the entire facility. Behind me in this pic is 3 racks of radios/routers/combiners/duplexers/etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2501173
>How oft do you have issues with homeless and the like?
Once every year or two, a site I deal with gets broken into. Sometimes it's shitbags just being shitbags, wanting to get into something they're not supposed to and cause a little mayhem. Other times it's copper thieves (cables/wire, grounding busbars are a big target). Sometimes it's druggies/homeless/undesireables.
Every now and then there's the adventure-seekers who want to climb the tower "just because". I can't blame them too much for that, it's part of why I got into the job. But them doing so without training/equipment puts huge liability on site owners/operators, and there's the risk of damage to the equipment on the tower.

Nowadays, just about every site's got cameras and alarms on it. I know as soon as someone's on the site, even just wandering around looking at things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2501311
This site's got a real creepy feel to it. There's a bunch of fed/gov equipment up here. Cables with tags on it that read "SECRET SERVICE".
One room has expanded metal lag-bolted to the walls, its own telephone circuits, and a lot of electronic equipment with no brands/identifiers that i've never seen anywhere else in my career. Another room has seahorses painted on the walls. Phone books from the 80s/90s. Cabinets with no license/contact info on them, simply a "Cabinet ID" sticker.

And "The Red Phone".

>fucking hantavirus
site owners call this room "the rat room". it smells like death and nobody ever goes in there.

Some of these sites are like a trip back in time. Cellular tech disrupted a lot of other wireless industries. Racks and racks of equipment for large businesses to acquire telemetry, sensor data, vehicle positions, etc all got replaced with little 3G/LTE radios riding on cell carrier's infrastructure. Cheaper to leave the vintage equipment on site and let it rot, to be "someone else's problem", than haul it down the mountain and dispose of it otherwise.

>Seems like a nice view in the background.
For sure. Some sites are prettier than others, there's some I enjoy going to for the drive/ride up to and views from the site. Might post a few of those pics here.

Generally, comm sites are "seen one, seen 'em all". Shack, tower, couple dishes, couple antennas, routers/radios/power equipment in the rack. All the same shit. But each site has its own personality.
Some are creepy like >>2500963 fallout shelter shit.
Some are pretty. >>2502568 dish shoots to >picrel site, and >picrel dish shoots over to >>2501316.
Some are full of character/history. Others are full of critters. Service trip to one site this year, one of the techs closed his email with "Say hi to the rat for me." Rat the size of his boot scared him when it ran across the floor as he was setting up in the building, I was outside getting geared up to climb and heard him scream. That was a fun site build except for the wind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503525
>Is there any danger in being so close to the antennas?
The 2way/LMR stuff isn't too bad. 100 watts or so with a couple dB antenna gain on it. Unless you're really close to it or working on the specific antenna when it's still lit up, there's not much of an exposure hazard. Those duty-cycle too, they're only on when someone's using the talk path, so overall exposure is reduced because of the time factor.
Dishes or directional antennas focus that energy in one direction; while they usually have less power into them, all that power is directed one way. Don't stand or work in front of those.
Broadcast transmitters are the scary ones. Lots of power, 100% duty cycle, and they're usually in bands that the body absorbs easily.
The tower in >picrel is AM broadcast, the tower structure is the antenna and it's electrically hot. Knocked power down while we were on it, less for exposure and more to minimize the risk of RF burns in case of accidental contact with the grounded cables I was installing. See https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b9UO9tn4MpI
On top of that tower was a 10-element FM broadcast array with about 50kW out of it.
When I climbed up to set an anchor the day before the install, knowing the two of us were only going to be up there for a short time, we didn't mess with the FM power levels. My alarm got real alarmy up there because of that exposure. The next day during the install, I coordinated with station engineer to ramp down power on that transmitter to acceptable levels while I was working ~15ft below that array.

Part of my pre-climb safety assessment includes RF exposure considerations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In theory, you can't live in a 'temporary' structure like this in Scotland unless it adheres to the same rules any 'permanent' building has to meet (planning permission, irrigation standards, etc.). If you buy land and do nothing with it (i.e., don't apply for planning or commercial permits) the government will be suspicious and send people to check. In practice, you could almost certainly get away with it if there was already a compliant, permanent structure on the land, because they'd never suspect someone would own such a place and choose to live in a temporary alternative. As such you wouldn't appear on their "watch lists". That might not be realistic for you but, basically, if you find a site with a small, crap house that's up to code, you can get away with doing what you want after that.
