Wildland Firefighting will have you camping on the job, but the conditions and pay are fucking awful. It's mostly seasonal, and they are NOT expecting to see you back that next season, they will treat you like shit and work you to the bone to protect some faggot's 50 million dollar estate in California. Out of the 4 jobs I've worked, this was the most brutal, but being on those conditions with like-minded individuals feels pretty rewarding.

After I did a summer in Cali, I went back home and worked as a Park Ranger for a couple of years. I thought it was going to be trail janny or fake forest cop work, but I never got to do any trail restoration, apparently that's for the Wildlife and Fisheries guys. What I did do, was more wildland firefighting, controlled burns and just random wildfires. Very rarely we would go out to random areas with biologists to take samples, it was mostly sitting on my ass in an office waiting for something to happen. I liked it alright, the people were nice but the pay was abysmal. I was told in the interview that the salary was set at $20,400 per year and it's unable to be changed. It was also a normal 5 days a week 9-5 which gets on my nerves.

Now I'm just a normal rural firefighter, which funny enough I still go with the Park Rangers to do controlled burns or wildfires close to houses, I just get paid almost triple the amount and only work two 24-hour shifts and fuck off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Did a 1200 mile thruhike earlier this year. Never used poles before this hike. A ranger in Glacier told me that when he did the PCT in the 80’s he was the only one using poles, by the end of his hike everyone had poles. I bought poles about halfway through my hike and the difference is pretty incredible. Your ankles, knees and hips stop absorbing all the shock of downhills. Going up Mt Constance from the Dosiwallips river in the Olympics is something like 4500 feet in 3.5 miles. Having the poles was much better than not.

As far as cons go, you’re carrying extra weight for something that’s not always useful. The AT has the most elevation change of any trail, that’s why most AT hikers use them. Same with the PCT, same with the CDT. But some people are retarded and don’t understand the limitations. Quite a few people were trying to use their poles going over rock fields and class 3 scrambling, fucking up their mobility and putting themselves in danger because they couldn’t just put them away. One couple out on the coast was even using their poles while trying to scramble over wet rocks and cliffs near high tide. Dumb bitch actually asked me how I was able to do it without poles. I used my hands you fucktard.

Now that I’m back on the east coast I’m not bothering to take my poles out anytime soon. Anyone who thinks poles are universally a bad choice deserves to have their knees destroyed, only yourselves to blame

You can also try and use knee compression sleeves and the waist belt of your backpack high over your hips to help you feel and keep your core and the muscles around your knees activated.

basic things:
don't heelstep
keep your core activated
small steps

There's a monster desert mountain ridgeline trail near me, with huge drops on either side, rocks and cactus everywhere, and the narrow trail gets wildly overgrown. It's a huge climb up to it, then it constantly goes up and down thousands of feet the whole time, and then you have to come back down an insanely steep canyon trail.
>brother and I tried to hike this ridge as boy scouts decades ago
>literal retards in troop slowed us all down so we had to bail down a side canyon
>brother wants revenge
>I decide to go without training
>halfway through, my quads decide they're done, so ascending becomes very slow
>make it to the end of the ridge
>start descending basically vertical canyon
>poles keep me stable but even with them each step down is very painful
>thousands of steps down and about 3 miles to go
>make it

Poles aren't always necessary or helpful and aren't some magic bullet, but use the right tools for the job.

Sorry, I've been ignoring /out/ for a while.

First of all, let it dry for a week or so in a cool, dry place with the bark still on (removing the bark right away could cause the wood to dry too quickly and crack), then strip off all the bark and let it dry for another week or two. Trim it however you wish, but an oscillating multitool is fantastic for precisely trimming knobs/knots almost flush with the surface.

First of all, sand it down real good. I do this by hand with a sheet because it's the best way and not terribly labor-intensive. Use 80 grit, then 180 grit; grip the shaft pornographically with the hand holding the sandpaper, then rotate back and forth while working slowly down the entire length. Repeat as necessary; buff problem spots; spend time smoothing down the stumps of the knobs and knots you trimmed.

For the very first coat after sanding, use orange oil or some kind of cutting board oil to fill up the pores a bit. Let it soak in for a while, then wipe the staff dry.

Melt the beeswax ((in a double boiler, tea candle warmer, etc.), and apply a generous coat with a cotton cloth. Wait at least an hour for the wax to soak in and set, then buff it out, again with a cotton cloth. This is the most labor-intensive part, as you do fast circles with two fingers under the cotton over the entire surface.

Repeat the wax coating and buffing 5-6 times.

The super-shiny staves you see in stores have been sprayed with polyurethane. Absolute crap.

I live in the PNW and in the winter any deadfall lying on the ground is 100% soaked all the way through. It simply will not burn without drying it by the fire beforehand. To collect dry firewood in the winter I have to find standing deadfall (where the top hasn't been broken off), cut it down with a saw, saw it into usable pieces, and chop those into firewood with an axe or hatchet. I process those down into kindling to get the fire started.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2506626
I'm about to dork out for a sec, sorry in advance. Yes, it's possible, but it would be very inefficient (in a colloquial sense, hydropower is actually very efficient going over 70%). Your idea is similar to what is known as "run-of-the-river" hydropower, where wheels are placed in rivers, often with small dams. The amount of power generated by the water is defined by the formula: P = ρ*G*h*g, where ρ is the density of water (about 1000 kg/m^3), G is the volumetric flow rate (m^3/s), h is the head (how far the water actually falls, in meters), g is gravity (9.81 m/s^2), and P is in watts.
Let's say you want to charge your phone, which requires about 5W. I'm going to make the generous assumption that you built this system with a head of about 8 meters (a little over a 2 story house). That would mean a value for G(volumetric flow rate) of about 0.000065 m^3/s is required, or about 1 gallon per minute (lots of estimations being made). Neglecting generator efficiency, you would be able to charge your phone if you manage to get a gallon of water per minute through your gutters.
This is an incredibly idealized scenario. In the video linked by someone else in the thread, the guy planned for a 2 watt system, but only ended up getting about 0.25 watts. You need to take into account actual head (in the drawing you posted, the head for each generator would be the distance from the gutter to the first wheel), generator efficiency, losses from storage (assuming you want to capture all of the energy and store it into batteries for later use), and frictional losses.
There are lithium batteries used to store energy with a capacity of 1200Wh, or 4.3 million joules. For the guy in the video, if the rain was generating 0.25 W like in his demo, he would be able to store 900 joules in an hour of rainfall. It would take 4800 hours of rainfall to charge that lithium battery.
You'd have to build many of these systems in parallel to capture a significant amount of energy.

posts.sub: Beginner Gear General - Poor Fag Edition
posts.com:
I wanted to make a thread for General new gear and where to get it. Also for Larpers and Woodsman alike to avoid the pit falls I fell into when choosing gear for the first time over 2 years ago. i'll try to aim for a good gear loadout under 200$. Also any criticisms or better options should be talked about here.

Ill first go by stating the things no anon should ever cheap out on.
>boots
you should aim for boots over 200$ price range eventually, but if you are just getting started buy military surplus boots. But If you can avoid do not buy the recent desert tan army boots that run 20$. They have very thick soles and no ankle support , its a good way to give yourself a sprang ankle, they are also not very breathable or water proof. But I used them for a year so they are workable but do have a week or 2 brake in period.

Next is backpacks I see many on here choose a military surplus backpack, My experience with a US military molle 2 rucksack is that its usable at best but too heavy. Military sacrifices price and quality material for an indestructible pack that an idiot can't destroy. You are better off with a used frame backpack or internal backpack.

I have found that most milltary backpacks are around 65-120$ a used backpacking bag is around 20$ on shopgoodwill.com. I hear you say that you don't want to stand out in the woods , I would say their are plenty of waterproof rain flys for your bag that come in non-IRreflective camo for 45$ or a Chinese rain fly for 10$ on amazon, which are better than what ever camo you were thinking about buying any how. A good capacity is 65 liters, this is considered 3 day bag but if your smart you can fit rations for a full week in it. 55 liters is fine but the limit for fitting a sleeping bag and not limiting the gear you might want to take. Finally you need to have a waist support for your backpack as well as a frame , this should go without saying a duffel bag is a pain to hull around 5 miles.

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2503231
>Sleeping mat
The next As far as Sleeping set ups go, a blue walmart foam sleeping mat as pictured above is pretty good and cost 10$. You can get a blowup mattress but without putting plenty of money into it you won't get much more out of it. Stay on the Osark trail for the moment. This is essential gear by the way you get much more out of a shitty sleeping bag when you have a mat to insulate you.

>Sleeping bag

If you are up north you should buy one sleeping bag thats rated for -20 degrees. Military arctic sleeping bags do this and are 50$ on colemans surplus. If you are down south you can get yourself a 15-0 degree sleeping bag and be just fine even in the middle of the winter in the mountains. All of these sleeping bags will be really big and around 40$ , I would try for shopgoodwill.com or walk to osarktrail down to walmart to try to find someone. Or just go for the -20 degree one and deal with it being extra hot and carrying 7 pounds.

>Compression sacks
they are great but you don't need them , but be prepared to have your shitty sleeping bag take up most of your main compartment in your bag.
20$ get one that holds 10 liters.

I'll talk about gear later

posts.com:
Cheap gear just ends up being more expensive long term. Yeah you can buy a few things used or military surplus, but it's better to save up and get gear that will actually last and perform adequately. No you don't need a 900 dollar feathered friends sleeping bag starting out, but you should invest in something that's decent so you don't throw away after 3 uses because it's trash. 200 dollars is laughably little for just a pack, boots, sleeping bag, and tent, let alone the dozen other items you'll want for an over nighter.

For basics I'd budget 100 each for boots and socks, a base layer, pants and a mid layer, backpack, a cook system, then 150 dollars each for a tent, sleeping bag and pad, 50 dollars each for sunglasses and a hat, axe or saw, good multi tool (on sale), headlamp. That will get you quality items you can use for years or even decades.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: You should spend a lot of money on boots everything else just take what you can find me and my friends hike with beat up mislurp packs and ancient second hand gear people in the past used to carry huge loads with rope and sticks don't overthink it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503248
>tent
Most likely you are too poor for a tent. I bought a surplus french 2 person tent and it was a bad decision. I slept in the tent with my wife and we woke up and the walls were super wet. So I water proofed it thinking it rained during the night when we went out. Still happened, It turned out it was just from our breath and the tent didn't have enough ventilation. I got a 3 person backpacking tent that is now a discontinued kmart brand and its the best tent and when it came out was around 35$ when I was a kid in the 2000s. But I can't seem to find any wall mart tent that 3 person and only 5 pounds. But I think a 1 person or two person for a solo camper should be cheap, but remember if your backpacking 2 person just means you and your pack, 3 person means you , a friend and your packs. Ultralite tents that use treking poles are nice but you better bring a tarp or the ground will ruin them.

>Hammock
This is your best option and you can get one for 20$ with a net on ebay. If you have a costco membership which I doubt you would they are like 10$ right now and are of serviceable quality. You can tie your sleeping bag around the tree and it will sit in your hammock really well. It also is really small and light weight.
>Bivy
only used them when I was young, kinda expensive but I am sure the surplus market has them for cheap.

>Tarp
You can do magic with tarps ,and if your really poor its the best way to go out. 3$ sometimes at harbor freight. speaking of harbor freight their hatchet are not a bad deal.

>Stuff to cut wood
You can buy a pruning folding saw , its the same thing as a camping folding saw and only costs 7.25 and has lasted me 3 years. I don't really like to take anything else camping to cut wood, besides if I have a job where I need to take an Ax.

>Medical kit
Just make it yourself and take what you think you'll need. Moleskin is underrated and should be in any medical kit as well as one bottle of antibiotics, aspirin and bandaids.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503310
Its more expensive but I still disagree with this sort of mentality, you have to get out now! The time you waste inside you will never get back. I would do it through any means you can. So the money is well spent and you can always have a friend who will take or use your old gear.

200$ gear is what I used for years and some of my best trips have been with my budget gear. some of it I got for free from friends and family , the military boots were free and the first pair of boots I've owned.

You gotta know bad gear to know good gear, and you gotta go out to figure out what actually works. I think the most fun I had was trying to figure out my poor fag loadout. This thread is most of my solutions to the problems I had with it and for new people starting out to start out with a better foot.

>shouldn't cheap out on boots or backpack
for short trips you don't need much comfort but on longer trips with several hundred km most people need the best they can get in terms of boots and backpacks so the impact on health is lessened. There is always some negative impact on serious long trips even with the best gear, unless you are young and very fit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Every time I come to /out/ I'm reminded I live in a different mindset than most everyone else here. Embrace the suck is just a way of life for me now when it comes to camping. I can be uncomfortable and still enjoy the experience.

I tell all beginners to grab any backpack any duffel bag or any garbage bag and fill it up with your typical outside clothes, a tent, and some food and water and then go sleep over night in your moms back yard. You will learn from that simple overnight with just a tent and the clothes on your back that YOU CAN DO IT. You can camp just like that; it doesn't have to be some ordeal. You're not going to be venturing out into some public land for a week long walker if you're a beginner so stop worrying about all the gear talk.

>>2503310
agree the price to performance ratio usually doesn't fall off until mid tier gear. but op's trying to put together a gear list more akin to the famous 'ultralighter shoestring budget' list for anons that just want to get into camping with a couple hundred bucks.
there are some disagreements i have though:
cook systems can be virtually free. my diy hobo alcohol stove cost $30 total in materials including the soda pops and its just as nice as my off the shelf high end canister kitchen.
mid-layers can be virtually free. costco sells polartec 100 sweaters for $8 and i see them all the time for about the same at goodwill. ecwcs base-layers or generic cheap polyester base-layers from walmart aren't actually that far off from my $400 wool set. one of the best the best shell jackets on the market is $20 at walmart (frog toggs ul2.) cheap gas station sunglasses are fine virtually everything thats made by luxotttica is the same so you're only getting anything better if you buy oakleys/etc. i'm a richfag and my hat is a $6 nylon tactical cap from amazon. synthetic beanies aren't great but get the job done for $5. etc. boots are more of a luxury than a mandatory item for beginners assuming they already own a pair of running shoes they don't mind beating up.
socks, backpack, tent/tarp, and sleeping bag are the ones that should never be cheaped out on or isn't worth it to. any other item i can show you a usable poorfag option. socks can be cheaped out on but its not worth it to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503524
>Gear
>Hatchet
15$ harbor freight hatchet is fine but try to get a budget hatchet with a cover for the blade.
>Pruning saw / Folding saw
10$ at a home depot or online, this is better than a hatchet.
>Fire
Matches or bic lighter
>Mess Kit
Walmart mess kit would be fine they are like 6$
bring a wooden spoon
>metal spork
2$ or just bring normal silverware

>Water purification
Campden tablets are 12$ and will purify most water without dirt inside. You can also get an expandable water jug for 6$ , just make sure to wash it out first or all your water will taste like plastic

>Food
I have alot of food that many I have not seen many talk about here. But ill start off with the obvious.
>Asian supermarket alternatives
>Ramen
Ramen is fine but if you want different flavors , an Asian super market has more flavors of Ramen than you might think
>Camping hot pot
This exists and might be worth it just going to put it out as an option
>1000 year egg
these fermented eggs are really black and smell like cheese, and last forever
>Quail eggs in a can
Yeah if you want normal eggs quail eggs do pretty well
> Items from the west
>Eggs
If you just cover your eggs in vasline they will keep for weeks since the air won't spoil them, same thing as the 1000 year egg but less time and less of a cheese flavor.
>Canned Food
Its good and cheap , water weight kinda sucks but its something to deal with.
>Meat balls
make your own meatballs and freeze them , then add them to a soup.
>Freeze dried chicken, bouillon cubes, and dried mushroom
This is a food you can assemble into a plastic bag and will keep for maybe years, you can get the freeze dried meat online.
>MRE
I know you might be tempted to use MREs and thats fine, but read the date to see if they are expired also they are tough to digest.
>Grits ,other ground corn ,oatmeal
These are also great

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2476498
Hey OP, good to see another future sailor!
I bought a good condition Catalina 22 off Craigslist in 2021 with no sailing experience besides hanging out for a few hours on a boat drinking. Finally put it on the water earlier this year and have been sailing as much as I could ever since, teaching myself all that I can along the way!
Sailing is a lot like shooting a gun or going for a run - anybody can do it, but it takes practice to do it well.
Money is a factor, that much is true, but it’s all relative. I got my boat for 4k off Craigslist - great sailing condition but the inside upholstery was/is in a rough condition. Other people were offering a lot more for it but the guy I bought it from accepted my offer early on and stuck with it. I’m glad he did! I did have problems with the outboard motor though and couldn’t fix it, then it popped off the mount and into the water so I replaced it with an electric engine and battery. My ePropulsion setup cost more than the boat but it’s reliable as shit and zero maintenance. My Cat22 came with a trailer and let me tell you what - it’s a good thing to have if you’re moving / need to move the boat for hurricane evac or something, but unless it’s a small Hobie Cat or sailing dinghy, trailering a sailboat sucks. It’s all the pain of normally trailering a boat plus the long setup of the mast and rigging. If you’re gonna get any boat with at least an outboard, keep it on the water full time.
I’ll continue in another post.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2476658
I live in the coastal GA area and have my boat on a wet slip and pay $312 a month. I love sailing, it’s my favorite hobby, and considering it costs $150 to charter a sailboat for an hour down here, I break even if I take my boat out for only 2hr a month. My only issue with being on the water is that my boat is on a river with a strong current only a few miles from the ocean, so depending on the tide and where my boat is moored, I have to wait for favorable conditions or get trapped in the marina. Additionally, when I do go sailing in zero/light winds, it means I’m fighting the current hard either going out or coming in at which point I’m just motoring. You’ll have more freedom from the elements on lakes, and more open water access on oceans, but it’s great being really in tune with nature. My gf gets bored on the water but there are few things better than cruising under sail with just the wind, no engine, and joining the dolphins, fish, and birds as you all live your life /out/doors.
Overall I highly recommend sailing, 10/10. I need to learn to tighten my rigging a bit and need more practice with the jib and properly using the mainsail, but it’s all good - there aren’t any mistakes, just lessons! I’ll pay for some proper sailing classes in the near future to learn some advanced stuff and coastal navigation, but as long as you want to get out on the water, by all means go for it!
>pic taken from the back of my boat as I tied stuff down 2 days before hurricane Ian passed by

Capri 25 owner here, somewhere between 2 and 3k is reasonable for hull painting, esp if you're getting copper paint. If you're actually willing to throw 10k at the boat it's gonna be in good shape by the time you're all set up, but that's a lot of money to spend on a 27, especially in one year. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ancient Sailing Fag here. Learn to sail in a dinghy. Get something small and learn to kick ass in it. Then get into that Catalina 27 and sail it like a dinghy. I've seen people start with a bigger keelboat and it scares the crap out of them or they get overwhelmed and give up. You need a Sea Daddy to show you the ropes. Go crew for somebody for awhile. Sail with your uncle. Then when you're comfortable when the boat heels too hard, you're ready to sail your own.
Also, solo sailing is a young mans game. Anybody can do it in good weather but when it gets "nautical" you have a lot to do really fast or you can get in trouble. It's best to accumulate a bunch of people that want to learn too and build your own crew. Plus it's a lot more fun to have a bunch of good friends partying with you every time you get on the boat.
The Catalina 27 is a great boat. You're not crossing any oceans in it, but if you stay on top of your maintenance it's a well designed and safe boat. So if the deal is really good, get it. But spend a year in a dinghy and crewing for someone else before you take it out by yourself or with an inexperienced crew.

>>2486273
I'd get the sailboat over the Porsche, but that's just me. It seems like a good opportunity for you. Getting it from family that hopefully you trust and know they won't fuck you over with a shitty boat/hidden issues makes it even better. Sailing is a lot of fun, but keep in mind it's also constant maintenance and replacements. You're either learning to do the work yourself, or paying big bucks for someone else to. Much more so than your truck camper or a new 911. Not trying to dissuade you, just trying to reinforce that it's not all the glamour that most sailing vlogs make it out to be. Kevin Boothby's YT channel is a good one that shows the bad along with the good.

Overall I say go for it, but I agree with others ITT that it would be a good idea take a basic keelboat lesson at least. Capri 22s, dinghies, something smaller than your 27. Generally the bigger the boat the less you feel what it's doing and the longer it takes to react to changes in trim/helm. IME newbies also start getting nervous when the heel angle goes over 20*, let alone 30*. Lessons with an experienced sailor help you get comfortable with how the boat behaves much quicker.

>t. lake sailor in Georgia that was only going to take lessons and then find his own boat, but joined the boat club instead

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507423
This is the correct answer.

If OP wants to go over the top, he can cut a donut of moleskin to fit around the affected area. Then dress the entire thing (wound and moleskin donut) with a simple gauze pad, then tape over the gauze.

The moleskin provides cushioning, the gauze keeps the wound clean, and the tape holds it all together. Leukotape holds better than duct tape, but everyone already has duct tape. This method is a pain in the ass because cutting a new donut of moleskin to change the gauze pad is a pain, but it’s the most comfortable. I’ve used little strips of moleskin to form a square around blisters and it works well. I’ve also just slapped tape over a popped blister and it wasn’t that bad.

The last time I treated a blister I just used gauze and leukotape. The moleskin donut (which is how it’s recommended to be used for blister treatment) isn’t really worth it. But some people are more sensitive.

Fun fact. The virgin river runs through Zion NP to make by way of the narrows.
But it was actually originally named the Severe River. Because of how violent and unpredictable it is sometimes nearly dry, other times flash flooding.
Because of a mix-up by a cartographer. Names were switched with the real Virgin river. Which is a peaceful, timid stream that is always wet, like a young virgin. It is now called the severe river.
It's a funny historical tidbit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Welcome to my blog. I did a 1200 mile thru hike this summer and was underprepared in many ways. About 600 miles in I woke up late one day in the Pasayten Wilderness and aimed for about 25 miles. Coming up to Cathedral Pass the rain clouds that had been dogging me all day suddenly landed right on top of me. I could see Cathedral in the distance getting pelted with sheets of rain. Realized I might die and was overjoyed at this prospect so I kept walking. It was rain at first, then hail and sleet, then snow. 3 inches of water flowing down the trail. No flat ground to speak of. Ball lightning striking the peaks above me. My pack was lined in a contractor bag. My rain layer wet out in a matter of minutes. Started shaking so violently I couldn’t walk a straight line anymore. I told myself I’d stop as soon as I found a spot to set the tent out. Found a patch of somewhat level ground and managed to set my tent up in the rain while shaking violently with blue fingers. Climbed inside, stripped everything off, climbed into my dry 20 degree quilt. Shook violently and contemplated death for about an hour and half while reading an ebook on my phone. It stopped raining so I put my dry clothes on and walked another 5 miles. Now I always carry an emergency blanket and preemptively take shelter to avoid rain if possible. Cold and wet is a death sentence

>>2502360
As hypothermia sets in it becomes difficult - later impossible - for your body to maintain a safe core temperature even if you're moving around. Women have it harder, and she may have had circulatory issues that made her even more susceptible. Even more so if either of them hadn't eaten in a while.

The solution I was trained with in cases of minor hypothermia is to wrap up person in a massive insulating burrito of a tarp, sleeping pad, and sleeping bag or at least get them in an insulated environment with a heat source. They weren't prepared for either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508548
>4.4 million people went through RMNP last year, that's still 400k on the trails
Not quite. Of the <10% who do venture more than 1/4 mile from their vehicles, some fraction will go 1/2 or 3/4 but no more than that, and still another fraction will go a mile or two, but no more than that.

Only a few % will actually travel miles and miles away from their vehicles. Great Smoky Mountains NP sees 400,000 hikers per year, though, but it has a lot more trails.

You're probably looking at 6-8 hikers per linear mile of trail in both GSMNP and RMNP, which isn't great, but then again these are hugely popular NPs.

In the backcountry of either park, you could probably go for miles/days without seeing a soul, if you're a bit lucky.

If you want solitude, don't go to a NP. In NPs you're generally required to stick to established campsites and not clear "previously undisturbed ground," so even in the backcountry you may find a desired backcountry campsite already occupied.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2500113
>What would your plan exactly be in case of accident if not calling for help, retard?
Greetings, dayhiker.

If you're underdressed and underprepared, and you cease physical exertion (leading to a significant drop in core temp) due to an injury, you'll have hours at the very most in windy, near-zero weather to call for help before you die. Additionally, being injured can lead to shock and other reactive symptoms.

So you'll still be signaling for help if you break your ankle, but if you have an emergency blanket, extra layers, bivvy, heat sources and fuel, etc., you'll love long enough for that to maybe save you. Also, a rape whistle, a flare gun, signal mirror, and/or EMS beacon are much more effective than yelling.

Be prepared, be spared.

>>2500185
>Someone tell how difficult this three mountains are.
Technically, not very. The weather however, is the among the worst on the planet. The highest recorded wind speed not in a hurricane or tropical cyclone was recorded on Mount Washington within the range at over 375 km/h, and it is regularly cold as Antarctica in the winter. Simultaneously, the range lies at the nexus of almost every major wind current in North America and is wildly unpredictable. People die from hypothermia in the middle of July on sunny days occasionally and things can change in an instant.

Her experience from the looks of it was 40 mountains in the range (done mostly in summer from the looks of it) so she wasn’t a total novice but I suspect she never had seen real winter conditions before if she went to trail run above tree line on a weekend with terrible weather. Her mother apparently said that she was trying to finish the 48 4000ers peak bagging list for New England prior to her birthday (today) so they had rented out a fucking hotel room of all things near the mountains and she was chauffeuring the daughter around.

A similar case to look at would be Kate Matrosova who did basically the same thing, but probably knew better.

>>2505532
Foxhunters usually won't go after you unless you are:
>Blasting the airwaves with massive power above the limit
>Shitting all over the frequency bands with crappy equipment causing spurious E
>Or deliberately jamming
>Being profane, inconsiderate, playing music, being commercialized, etc.
>Sitting on a frequency for hours, or otherwise being annoying enough to attract unwanted attention

You could always run into someone with a bug up their ass and something to prove, but that's the risk you run. A handheld, with low TX power, on the move, in the backcountry? You can probably operate without detection.
That said, the technician class license is easy and lets you legally transmit with all VHF/UHF radios right off the bat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508281
>what do i need
Only out gear you need is something to sleep in so get a sleeping bag or wool blanket, a hammock or a sleeping pad will make the experience much nicer. From there, you might need a shelter is weather is bad, so a home depot tarp will work just fine, a purpose made ultralite tarp is a good investment if you’re serious, in fact, if you’re buying new gear, it should all be ultralite, hurting your joints because you’re too cheap to pay a bit more than 50 year old milsurp is silly, or a tent. If you want a fire, you’ll need a fire starter, a bic lighter is all you need. Water, your choice on how to carry it. Food, longer trips peanut butter + tortillas, shorter larps, anything to cook over the fire. A knife is a good thing to have on you, any will do, mora is a good cheap choice but even swiss army keychain knife will handle opening your food parcels. After that anything else is larping or to make a task easier or safer - you can break downfall on your knee to process it but an axe or folding saw will help you larp as a real man for a night. Drop any further questions here, I probably have the most experience on this board

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
No I wouldn't, I am an anxious fuck who does horribly in most social situations and regularly tries to remove myself from the hustle and bustle to recenter. But I have relationships built, forged and tempered through some shit that I wouldn't be able to stomach letting go of... and that's just the emotional/ spiritual side of it for me, that doesn't at all include the practical and logical side of things.
You will get worn down, you will get sick, you will get hurt, you will age. How one handles those things by themselves is preparation of course, but you can't prepare your way out of a broken wrist and needing to split wood for the coming snowstorm without an extra pair of hands.
I know a guy in his 70s who spent roughly 40 years on his own up in the mountains and he's one hell of a man, but I know him... which means he eventually left that isolation.. his reasons are his to know but there's one thing he's for damn sure taught me.
You can't do it all yourself, and having someone that cares enough about you to want to help is worth all the effort you can muster.
>tl;dr: You can only go so far on your own and if you do it good on you, just know you probably want it because your running from something you're scared to face... which is vulnerability with other people most likely.

The ideal life for a human being is in a tribe or tiny village. I have read somewhere that the human brain is made for forming bonds with a few dozen to a hundred people. When you live in a bigger place you're constantly surrounded with strangers and this is like an aggression. That's enough noise to make you feel like you're not alone in the physical sense, but those strong bonds are practically nonexistent. You have real bonds with your direct family and that's it. I know plenty of people who have marginal bonds with their own family because they're so busy. It's all so unnatural. Being completely alone to escape the hive is just as unnatural, but people think of it as a solution because it's way more manageable than finding a place where you can form those true bonds with someone. Many people do it on purpose to make the state of things seem reasonable,
>Ah you dislike modern society eh? Well then why don't you go live alone in the forest, see how you like it?
It's really fucked up. The truth is that things are so fucked that even the solutions we can think of are fucked. We're in a stupid world made of stupid people who can only think of insane solutions to insane problems. The truth is that nobody before things collapsed ever needed to think about this, that natural state was just there, you did not have to find it or somehow figure out that it is ideal because a study made by a bunch of scientists confirmed it. People do this to escape the city which is Hell. I don't even know how to talk to city people, they're like aliens. I don't like them, they don't like me. They enjoy things I find torturous. I don't even know if truly small communities of people who haven't been assimilated by the Borg still exist.

If any of you fags actually went outside, you'd know that ATVs and dirt bikes are banned in many National Forests, on some BLM land, etc. That's a very good thing, but the great majority of us posting here have jobs and shit. I would absolutely love to hike everywhere, but I just don't have three weeks free anytime I want to go fishing, hunting, or camping. Wish I did.

Anyway, an all-terrain e-bike is 1/3 (or less) the cost of an (actually good) mountain bike or a decent dirt bike, and will get me where I'm going. I haven't bought one yet, but I've seen them start to appear in local (and locally owned) outfitters whereas no outfitter used to ever carry e-bikes, so I think they're catching on for this specific reason.

If you can find me a $2,000 mountain bike that will handsomely handle not only trails but the primeval, unblazed forest terrain in Jefferson and GW National Forests, then I will buy it. But we all already know that mountain bikes like that start at $5-6k, and I go outdoors to hunt and fish primarily, not to ride a bike.

Dirt bike's out of the question, that's when Ranger Rick magically appears from behind a tree.

2: I wouldn't buy one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507444
Depends on the bike I'm taking. The yellow one, a little bivy tent or hammock. I'll bring a rain fly if I need it. Blanket or sleeping bag depending on the weather. A little emergency blanket in case I fucked up. Some tools in case shit goes wrong. Water, food, battery packs, AAA card, and all the shit I usually carry in my pockets. A little butane stove, a pot, water, and some mountain house shit. Some snacks. My cruiser has bags so I can bring a three man tent plus whatever else I want.

If you're going day by day you can cut weight and just get shit on the road before you call it a night. You have no reason to stock up on food and water other than what you need before you call it a night. Truck stops have showers if you're in the states, and some have laundry. Showers are usually around $15. If they've got a driver's lounge you can just pass out in one of the recliners. Sometimes you'll have those days where you just wanna ride until you can't ride anymore, and nobody cares if you wanna sleep in the lounge.
